reviews.review_title: This Movie Does NOT Deserve This Crap
reviews.content: I have been a mega horror movie fan my entire life. I have been using this site for many years and have never felt compelled to share my feelings about a movie until today. I have a deep love and appreciation for horror movies and I am very careful about which ones I spend money on in theaters watching. Not just because there are so many released every year that aren't worth the money to go see but because I can't stand the teenagers that ruin the experience in the theater for me so I just don't go most of the time. Just like all of you people, I read the terrible reviews given to this film by not just critics (because they are PAID to have an opinion) but the viewers and audience members were really mad about the ending. Needless to say that almost kept me from going to see this movie. This movie was in no way deserving of the negative and harsh reviews people are giving it. It seriously upsets me that good films are thrown in the trash because of ignorant people that have no business reviewing horror films. It is true that there are loose ends in this film. Like for instance the fact that they are in Italy and all the priests she hangs out with are English speaking with no accents, they do not take the time to develop the characters in a detailed degree and they don't even attempt to explain a lot of things that lead them through the plot. It is true, this film leaves a lot of questions unanswered. How is that something to be mad about? This is a horror movie, they are aiming to scare you, to shock you, to disgust you, they don't have to explain ANYTHING! In all reality the things that you don't see and the things they don't explain are usually the things that end up sticking with you the longest. For instance in the Blair Witch, we don't know what happens at the end really do we? All we see is dude standing up against the wall and then chick gets knocked out. We don't KNOW what happened. We THINK we know what is GOING to happen. THAT IS WHAT MAKES IT SCARY. NOT KNOWING IS SCARY! COMING UP WITH YOUR OWN TWISTED CONCLUSION IS ALWAYS FAR SCARIER THAN ANYTHING THAT ANOTHER PERSON CAN SHOW YOU IN A FILM. That is where knowing stops and imagination begins. We are as an American audience that is so used to having information spoon fed to us that we cannot invest any time actually thinking or investigating something. Idiots. That is what all you low-balling one star rating people are. IDIOTS.This movie has several wonderful scare scenes. My girlfriend crushed my hand during the first exorcism scene. That girl moved her body like she was truly possessed. Totally freaked us out when period blood started spewing from her crotch. Another cool part was when the demon finally left her and her entire body flew up in the air. Man.....that was awesome. Another sweet part was the part with the priest and the baptism of the baby. Dude. I did not think they would really have dude try to kill a baby in the movie. THEY WENT THERE. Not many horror movies go there just out of courtesy to the audience. This movie is like a honey badger it doesn't give a sheet. Oh yeah, it has priest drown a baby in a baptismal. Very shocking. VERY DISTURBING. Especially when he stares into the lens of the camera as he does it. That gave me nightmares. The part when the priest comes back to the house and what happens is really scary. One more thing before I end this rant. THE ENDING MADE SENSE YOU IDIOTS NEED TO WATCH THE MOVIE AGAIN. Yes it was very abrupt and we weren't expecting them to die like that but they did. The end result of the film gave me a feeling of absolute defeat. This group of demons were so powerful, they didn't stand a chance. Think back to the moment when the one priest is possessed and the other one is telling that priest that he can overcome these demons and stop them from killing them. He just cries and cries and says he can't and eventually blows his brains out right after delivering a line that gave me goosebumps. You know this movie was good. You just didn't like the ending because it wasn't a blockbuster grand finale of special effects that climaxes like a pig coming for the last thirty minutes. Stop crying, go wipe your crack and watch the movie again.The only part that I would have changed would be (like some of you other legit horror fans have said) making the mothers role a little bit more involved with the plot or even bringing her back at the end. She is the focus of the movie and the way the plot ends up directed towards the daughter and the priests and move away from the original story just confuses people and it irritates them and irritated audience members usually end up drawing unfair conclusions at the end of the film and give it crappy reviews because they didn't pay attention to the movie because they were irritated at the beginning. They should have thought about that. Plus, I thought she was amazing as an actress. She blew me away during that initial meeting scene when she starts talking about the aborted baby and screams at Isabella. That scene alone should make you guys really think about what you are saying when you give this movie a one star rating! I honestly think you people have no love for the horror genre and have no business talking crap about this movie. Shut up.:(

reviews.review_title: Save your time and money by watching the red band trailer instead...
reviews.content: In 1989, emergency responders received a 9-1-1 call from Maria Rossi confessing that she had brutally killed three people. 20 years later, her daughter Isabella seeks to understand the truth about what happened that night. She travels to the Centrino Hospital for the Criminally Insane in Italy where her mother has been locked away to determine if her mother is mentally ill or demonically possessed. When she recruits two young exorcists to cure her mom using unconventional methods combining both science and religion, they come face-to-face with pure evil in the form of four powerful demons possessing Maria. Many have been possessed by one; only one has been possessed by many. (Paramount Pictures)Just recently, Paramount Pictures was named the studio that topped the 2011 box office above all the other major studios. If they want any more people to show up to their films in 2012, they should stop green-lighting films like THE DEVIL INSIDE, although dumping it in January seems like the best decision to forget the film ever existed by the end of the year. Yes, the film produces more unintentional laughs than actual scares. Yes, many people will walk out feeling ripped off once the credits roll. And yes, THE DEVIL INSIDE is a bad film, unfortunately, although the incredible red band trailer suggests otherwise. However, the trailer spoils all the "good," jolting parts in the film. Surprise, surprise.As you can tell, there are many problems regarding the film. However, some of the ones that stand out are the incredibly slow pacing and the dull execution. The few, lazy, cheap scares the film has to offer, the only things left to salvage this dreck from a total waste, are few and far between. To say that the film was tedious to watch would be an understatement. Also, the documentary style serves more to harm than help the film, as every scene that should feel spontaneous and authentic, instead, feel rather staged. With the many problems the film has, the film's biggest crime is the abrupt ending, which is like getting slapped in the face. Just as the film is starting to pick up momentum, it ends as if the filmmakers ran out of budget. Note to all filmmakers: You don't want to anger audiences like that.The cast don't do much to help elevate the film either. Fernanda Andrade, the female lead, is merely serviceable although nothing memorable. However, Suzan Crowley, in the few scenes that she's in, is rather good for what she had to work with. I can't say much for the rest of the supporting cast, which includes Simon Quarterman, Evan Helmuth, and Ionut Grama. Grama, in particular, is incredibly bad as he tries to make his reactions and emotions feel real that it comes off as forced and awkward.I suppose the film will open reasonably well in the box office like most found footage films with low budgets and make a cheap buck before disappearing off in the world. However, I'm here to warn you not to give in to what appears to be a fun, scary night at the movie theater. It's a slow, dull film with barely any scares at all. Yes, the potential for the idea is there, but the execution is just bad. THE EXORCIST this is not.

The horror chiller "The Devil Inside" gives movies about exorcism a bad name. Face it, William Friedkin's "The Exorcist" (1973) still ranks as the best exorcist movie of all time. No other horror movie can match this landmark movie, least of all its lackluster sequels. Nevertheless, Hollywood continues to crank out new movies about exorcism as if Friedkin's "The Exorcist" had lost its vitality. Warner Brothers did the next best thing; they re-released Friedkin's frightening film back in 2010 in a revamped version that performed well at the box office. Lately, three exorcism movies have appeared. Sir Anthony Hopkins starred in "The Rite" back in the spring of 2011, and it emerged as a respectable hair-raiser. "The Rite" bore a PG-13 rating so it had little bite. The low-budget, Louisiana-set, yell-bent yarn "The Last Exorcism" preceded "The Rite" by several months, but it contained more irony than thrills. Now, Paramount Pictures has released writer & director William Brent Bell's "The Devil Inside," another misguided entry in the pseudo-documentary genre. Like the "Paranormal Activity" trilogy, "The Devil Inside" sets out to enhance its simulated verisimilitude by featuring a character that films the action as it unfolds. Sadly, none of the subtlety and artistry which made the "Paranormal Activity" epics so taut appears in this mercifully brusque 87-minute nonsense. Worse, "The Devil Inside" regales us with lukewarm exorcism scenes and overwrought performances. You know an exorcism movie is in trouble when a barking dog provides its scariest moment.Attractive Isabella Rossi (Brazilian-born actress Fernanda Andrade of "Why Am I Doing This?") is the adult daughter of Maria Rossi (Suzan Crowley of "Wild about Harry) who went bonkers back in 1989. "The Devil Inside" opens with Maria's cryptic 911 phone conversation and her confession that she has killed two priests and a nun during an exorcism. Afterward, we're treated to a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the gory crime scene; detectives wander through the blood-splattered residence in confidential footage mocked up to resemble grainy, old VHS tape. Later, Maria convinces the jury that she went insane, and she winds up heavily sedated in an asylum in Rome. The film fast-forwards to 2009. A grown-up Isabella, who was just a child when her mother slaughtered the priests, hires documentary filmmaker Michael Schaefer (Ionut Grama of "The Whistleblower") to chronicle her mom's case. Basically, she wants to prove whether her mom is possessed by a demon or mentally ill. Isabella and Michael fly to Rome to visit Maria. While she is in the Eternal City, Isabella sits in on a lecture about exorcism at a Catholic school for exorcists. Afterward, she meets with a couple of clerics, Father Ben Rawlings (Simon Quarterman of "The Scorpion King: Rise of a Warrior") and Father David Keane (Evan Helmuth of "Fever Pitch"), who have been conducting exorcisms secretly without the church's blessing. Rawlings tells Isabella to forgo any more exorcist lectures. Indeed, he invites her to an exorcist with David and him. Isabella's first exorcism occurs in the basement of a house in Rome. Rawlings and Keane use a number of gadgets to assist them. They outfit their patients with a heart monitor and photograph the size of their pupils to determine how crazy that they are. The young Italian girl, Rosa (Bonnie Morgan of "Piranha"), who they deal with spews some profanity and has her period. At one point, she breaks her bonds and scrambles up a wall like a roach, but the priests cast out the devil. Isabella is now prepared to meet her mom.Maria surprises Isabella when she reminds her daughter that an abortion that she consented to years before won't put her in God's good graces. Predictably, Isabella is shocked by this revelation from somebody who hasn't seen her in twenty years. Later, the Fathers hook Maria up to their gadgets, and she surprises them. Not only does she utter epithets in several tongues, but she also clobbers Father Rawlings and sends him reeling clean across the room. Nothing that either Isabella or the Fathers do convinces the Vatican to review Maria's case. As it turns out, the Vatican has washed its hands of the Rossi family. This surprises our protagonists despite the fact that Maria killed three ordained exorcists back in 1989. Meantime, Father Keane begins to feel paranoid, and he has good reason. The devil inside Maria has taken residence up in him! Unfortunately, this creates chaos of another kind that is calculate to make you cackle rather than cringe. Keane tries to drown a baby during a baptism and later relieves a Roman cop of his pistol and uses it on himself. Meantime, Michael is speechless at everything that he has lensed."The Devil Inside" isn't scary. The closest that Bell's film gets to scary is creepy. The last shot is a website where presumably all the answers can be found. Ultimately, however, creepy often becomes campy. The disclaimer at the outset that "the Vatican does not endorse this movie" shouldn't come as any surprise. Nothing in this pedestrian horror movie will either make your head spin or spew up green pea soup. Worse, Bell and co-producer Michael Peterman wrap up everything far too quickly with an abrupt ending. We're told to check out their website www.TheRossiFiles.com. Believe me, this is no way to end a movie, but then "The Devil Inside" isn't worth a pitch fork.

reviews.review_title: Terrible Excuse For A Film With The Worst Ending I've Ever Seen...
reviews.content: I had gotten quite absorbed by this film. It was quite entertaining and I thought they handled the, far too commonly used, documentary style relatively well, aside from the annoying acting of the cameraman.It sets up the story well enough and the majority of the characters are entertaining. I did not find myself feeling very scared by the film but this is common enough for myself and horror films, but I was quite entertained by the film waiting to see where it went.The story was developing nicely with the introduction into the world of exorcisms and discussing problems with the church's approach to them, I was feeling quite engaged. Then they finally establish the mother is possessed...as everyone knew anyway...and they go off to put their case to the church to do an exorcism, but this is made into a thing that they will have to fight for.Surely with this being set up, the viewer can expect a big climax in the form of the mother's exorcism? ... Nope. Instead the demon bounces around the characters in fairly boring fashion and kills them all...Worst ending to a horror film I think I have ever seen. To make it even worse, they stick in a website at the end to say go to this website to find out more about this unsolved case...this website is no longer online and when it was online was in fact just a promotional website for the film.It is an insult to the viewers. This film looks as if the makers ran out of budget halfway through the film and just decided they end it with what they'd filmed. It can hardly even be called an ending.Steer clear of this film! Waste of time! And an insult to the viewer!

There have been a great many films featuring exorcisms, and a lot of them pale in comparison to William Peter Blatty's 1973 film because a) there are only so many ways you can feature an exorcism, and b) that film has been banned in various medias on many occasions earning it a well deserved notoriety that is near impossible to topple.Where 'The Devil Inside' succeeds is that it follows the renegade priests who perform the ceremonies, alongside Isabella Rossi (Fernanda Andrade) as they try to keep up with various possessions, and makes them the focal points instead of the victim(s). Their main mission is helping Isabella's mother, Maria (Suzan Crowley), but that doesn't mean we're not treated to other examples of bulging-eyes and bone-popping as demonic forces rip through their unfortunate victims.This is also a 'found footage' film, which adds a further frenetic energy to proceedings - otherwise known as shaky camera syndrome. Some don't care for this genre, but I think that, if used well, it is still a very effective way of telling a story, from a personal viewpoint impossible to achieve with a more traditional approach. There's even a little self-awareness in the script: "I'm the annoying guy with the camera," the film-maker says at one point.I found 'The Devil Inside' thoroughly entertaining and occasionally visually shocking. Good to know also, that a production of this type can still provoke controversy from those eager to complain; the abruptness of the finale has caused some comment, but it works really well, I think: sometimes, there should be no happy ending. Not everyone was impressed, causing co-writer to actually spoon-feed his critics with a defence, saying, 'Sometimes real life doesn't follow a perfect structure. Things aren't always wrapped up and resolved when or how you'd like them to be.' That he should need to explain his creative decision is courteous, but exposes the power of 'the moaners'. Stuff 'em! My score is 8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: I really wanted it to be at least half decent.
reviews.content: This could have been a pretty effective film about demonic possession but suffers not only from some terrible acting but using a 'Lost, Found Footage' style, that has been rinsed so many times, it simply becomes annoying. That said two of the three (possession) scenes are rather good. Some atmospheric imagery along the way but in the end you get the feeling of being cheated.

I'm tired of exorcism movies, and I also don't like "fake documentary" style. (I hated "Paranormal Activity") These things considering I think this movie surpassed my expectations. Why I wanted to see it if I was prepared to dislike it? Well, I think it ended in my watchlist after I read some articles about catholic church's actual exorcisms that they even to this day conduct, though very rarely. I think that is an interesting topic, and I read this movie is to some extent inspired by true events. Well, that's a claim many horror movies make but it doesn't usually mean much.The documentary style at first distracted me because I wondered if some of the clips are from actual events (newsflashes and interviews). But I soon came to a conclusion it must be all staged for this movie. I like actual documentaries a lot, but in this case it felt a bit weird to watch one that is not real. Then again, if the Vatican doesn't allow to make a real documentary, it somehow makes sense to make one that is staged. And I started to like it for what it is. At least it is a fresh new take to the subject and not another Conjuring style basic horror film.I wouldn't rush to watch it again but I must say the movie kept me somewhat interested during its short running time. I might recommend it to those who are really fascinated about the subject matter.

You may remember the films The Fourth Kind and The Last Exorcism, pretending to be like some kind of realistic looking documentary with haunted houses and possessed people, but they just fails to convince or grip you, well this film is very reminiscent. Basically, on 30 October 1989, in South Hartford, Maria Rossi (Suzan Crowley) was arrested and sentenced to stay in South Hartford State Asylum, because two years previously she committed the murders of two priests and a nun, apparently while an exorcism was being performed on her, and some months later she was transferred to Centrino Mental Hospital in Italy. Twenty years later, Isabella Rossi (Fernanda Andrade), twenty five year old daughter of Maria, is making a documentary about exorcisms, and so she can find out more about her mother, and she is introduced to the process by priests Father Ben Rawlings (Simon Quarterman) and Father David Keane (Evan Helmuth). She joins them as they attempt to exorcise a demon from Rosalita/Rosa Sorlini (Bonnie Morgan), bringing medical equipment to determine if her behaviour is possession or mental illness, she is attacking, self-harming and shouting obscene comments in different languages and accents, she even speaks unknown Isabella's name, until they stop her. Isabella goes to visit her mother in the asylum, she has covered her walls in paintings, she can speak other languages and accents, and she has carved her own skin with crucifixes, including on her bottom lip, and her mother mentions that killing children is against God, and there is no way she would know her daughter had an abortion years ago. Maria is taken to have another exorcism performed on her, but the church does not approve the process without evidence of demonic possession, and during the procedure she breaks out of her restraints and throws Ben and David around, until the doctors come in to help the situation. All of this was filmed on camera and recorded for sound, and they present the evidence to the church, Ben and David both listen to and watch the footage again and again finding some meaning in the words and actions of Maria, in fact four demon voices were speaking, and soon another evil spirit appears during a baptism inside of Michael 'Mike' Schaefer (Ionut Grama), he tries to submerge the baby in the water before passing out. After this it appears that David himself may be the next victim to have a demon inside of him, as Ben finds him covered in blood, ranting and raving, the police arrive and he grabs an officer's gun and threatens to kill himself, and after attempting the words to The Lord's Prayer he shoots himself, and also watching Isabella has a seizure. Hysterical Ben realises soon that Isabella too is possessed, and in the hospital she causes a nurse to bleed and heavily and is attacking many others trying to restrain her, Ben and Michael take her away and get help for a possible exorcism, but while driving she attacks again and causes the car to go out of control, travelling into busy traffic, and the camera recording cuts out, the footage only returning in moments to see them all going through the windscreen. Also starring Brian Johnson as Lieutenant Dreyfus, John Prosky as Father Christopher Aimes, Claudiu Istodor as Doctor Antonio Costa and Claudiu Trandafir as Father Robert Gallo. The cast of unknown actors is pretty dull, even leading actress Andrade as the investigative filmmaker, the plot is nothing new and the "found footage" idea is predictable and silly, I admit a couple of the exorcism scenes have freaky and interesting enough moments, but that is not enough, and the film has a terrible ending and boring scenes in-between the action, it is not scary, not original and not worth seeing at all, a terrible supernatural horror thriller. Pretty poor!

It is enjoyable but I promise you will wish it ends differently, leaving you wanting your money back.

The Devil Inside (1:23, R) — fantasy: supernatural, bargain basement, formulaThe annual movie calendar cycles between feast and famine. There are 2 periods every year (Thanksgiving to the Super Bowl and the 1st half-dozen weeks of summer) when there's an abundance of wonderment everywhere you look. Not at all coincidentally, these fertile periods correspond to potential audiences having extra time off work and school. The December crest also has 2 other things going for it: (1) the holiday spending fever and (2) Hollywood's probably accurate perception that Academy Award voters have exceedingly short attention spans, so better save the really good stuff for the end of the year, so it's still fresh in their minds (and possibly even still playing in nearby theaters) come nomination time.But if those 2 bountiful stretches are like the lush Amazon rain forest, the months of January and February are like the Sahara Desert. The big holiday blockbusters still dominate the multiplex, and the films that were your 4th or 5th choices back when school let out are still the major attractors at the box office as people finally get around to seeing them. But some of the older releases have reached their sell-by date, the last reasonable nickel having been wrung out of them, and it's time for the available prints to head off to the cheap theaters, the boondocks, lucky foreign lands, or even just the vaults, to avoid competing with the upcoming DVD releases.The naïve would hope that the ax would fall first on the most deserving, such as The Darkest Hour or anything featuring vocal vermin. Ha. It is to laff. No, the primary target is the family- friendly animated stuff. (Kids are back in school, you know.) Thus this weekend we bid adieu to Happy Feet 2 (released Nov. 18) and Arthur Christmas (Nov. 23).Taking their places in the 40-seat auditoria are the low-stakes placeholders — featuring nobody you've ever heard of and production companies that purchased their transitory domain names from GoDaddy last June — that can probably recoup their production costs in the 1st week just from curiosity seekers (plus completists such as myself), before word of mouth gets out. Which brings us, after the foregoing shucking and jiving, to the subject of today's review, the unimaginative, formulaic exorcism flik The Devil Inside.The opening title cards solemnly assure us that, however many atrocities may be laid at the feet of the Catholic Church, this is not one of them. (They don't phrase it that way, of course.) I think this disclaimer is supposed to establish the "documentary's" rebel vibe — unofficial, unsanctioned by authority, the real story of demonic possession that the hierarchy doesn't want you to know.Ostensibly in late 2009, the "documentarian" follows a young woman across the sea to Italy, where her insane mother is being held in an asylum run by Catholic officialdom. Mom had offed 3 clergyfolk as they were trying to exorcise her back in 1989, and we're supposed to believe that the US was happy to be rid of her. Thus we get to see establishing shots of Rome as filmed thru the window of a moving vehicle and are later treated to ordinary Italians who speak a few subtitled words in their native language before unaccountably breaking out in spontaneous fits of English. The gal and her cameraman are soon joined by 2 ninja exorcists, Fathers Ben Rawlings (young, unshaven, British accent) and David Keane (older, fleshier, apparently American), who are studying at the Vatican's School of Exorcism but getting in lots of unsanctioned homework on the local population of possessees.They bicker between themselves as to how to tell the difference between someone who really is hosting a demon vs. merely the mentally ill, or somebody faking it for some unknown reason. Hint #1: There is no such thing as demonic possession, because there are no such things as demons. Hint #2: If there were, the dead giveaway is the Attack of the Lavender Eye Shadow.To give the illusion of authenticity, the movie makers employ the hand-held camera technique pioneered by The Blair Witch Project and actually done fairly well by Cloverfield. But those were done for the sake of art, with some deftness. Here it's just an early production decision, and once they get started, they don't let up, beating the gimmick to death with excessive wiggling and jiggling. The most incompetent documentarian in history — like, say, your dim 9-year-old cousin recording for posterity how he persuaded his even dimmer 7-year-old brother to ride his bicycle off the garage roof — had better camera work than this.Yada yada yada, screams, blood, contortions, self-doubt, recriminations, suicide, thankfully only a single cheap-thrill jumpatcha (hey, dog wranglers cost money, y'know), speaking in tongues, incredibly incompetent hospital management, inverted crosses carved into flesh, more cameras with improbable vantages, yada yada yada, scream, grab, more death, the end.On the unfathomable chance that you actually LIKE this sort of tripe, you'll probably feel gypped. The movie's run time of 1:23 was padded out by the slowest-moving end-credit crawl since the projector broke back in '73. You could probably have TYPED the credits out faster than they scrolled up the screen. (I know, I know, "The food was terrible, and the portions were so small.") This exceeds the "dime a minute" standard that you should be willing to pay for the very best.Why, then, that 2nd star? Bad as it was, it might have been worse. For a blessing, it didn't have a single singing rodent.

The movie was better than any other exorcism/exorcist movie I've seen. Definitely better than all the Paranormal Activities, but it was also low quality. The whole movie was very shaky, very few times was the camera held still. The angles the cameras were put in were kind of odd. The ending was absolutely terrible. There were parts that made you jump but for the most part, it was like any other documentary film about this kind of stuff. I would recommend it to anyone who likes the thrill of stuff like that, but for anybody else, do not waste your money. For the few parts that they actually showed an exorcism, compared to what the previews show, it wasn't worth it at all.

A summary line that is unfortunately true of most of those so called "scary movies" of late. I'm still amazed at the fact that they seem to make enough money to warrant even more of this. Than again you could argue that I did watch it too. Which is true and while I didn't go to a cinema to watch, the hype surrounding it was immense so I had to see for myself.This makes Paranormal Activity look like a masterpiece though. Whatever you think of that other movie (that spawned a Saw-like franchise), you can't really say it was that scary, if you have watched a lot of Horror movies. Nevertheless and back to this one, this is horrible from beginning to the end. But the wrong kind of horrible. The main actress did a movie a few years before this one called "Why am I doing this?". A fair question and something quite a lot of viewers might think about this too ...

The Plot:Maria Rossi (Suzan Crowley) killed three members of the Roman Catholic Church in 1989. She is sent over to Italy because the Vatican wants her for reasons that the media doesn't know. Twenty years later, Isabella (Fernanda Andrade) and Mike (Ionut Grama), the filmmaker, travels to Rome because she wants to know more about her mother and gathering information regarding of exorcism. Upon arriving she meets two priest Ben (Simon Quarterman) and David (Evan Helmuth) who has experience performing exorcism. They both agree to perform it, but they know there is a price to pay.The Content: Many of my friends have begged me not to see film due to the fact that they hate it. My job is to review films, no matter what people say because it is my hobby. The Devil Inside is an unholy mess. The only thing that I personally had no problem was the acting. It's not the best nor the worst, but its right there. Everything else was a complete disaster waiting to happen. First off, in order to get the audience attention, you need a plot that either makes sense or to make it interesting to the end. That was not the case for this film. One issue was that it failed to focus on the main plot when it was suppose to. Instead it mainly focused on the subplot, which is a big no-no. As an experience writer, you should not focus on your sub-plot as much, however you can show it or tell it, but mainly the screenwriters should have pay attention to the main plot. On top of fact, how many exorcism movies are out there? A lot and that is the problem because the audience is already recognizing the whole plot structure and you know where it is going to happen from A to Z. The hardest thing to do in modern cinemas is to scare the audiences. The main reason why it doesn't work anymore is due to the fact that it is getting repetitive. Let say it the movie came out in 1970s, than it would have shocking values but because were so used to it, it's not the same. Another issue that I came across was the pacing. Sure, it may be only 86 minutes, but it was the longest 86 minutes of my life. It dragged was due to the lost of interest. The only way I can see 86 minutes passing by is to do two things: the interest of the characters and again the plot. For example, in Alien (I recommend everyone to check this movie out) the film is slow but because it has good characters development and an interesting story, the film achieves well paced. This movie does not. The hardest thing to do in films is to end a movie. The Devil Inside will go down in history as one of the worst endings in film history. Never in my life have I laughed so hard because how terrible the ending was. The audience was slap in the face, which obliviously no one wants to experience. If you want me to tell you the ending, it will be a pleasure, otherwise just skipped to the next paragraph.Isabella is possessed. Ben wants to take her to another priest after his friends David killed himself. Mike is driving in the car along with Ben and Isabella. She is soon awaken and attacks Mike, but regains consensuses, but he shows sign of possession as well. He crashes the car and the screen goes black with some cuts showing chaos as the car tumbles. Then it cuts complete back and says this "The Rossi family case remain unsolved. For more information, go to www.therossifiles.com. What kind of ending is that?The Verdict: The Devil Inside is already my candidate as the worst film of the year, and the sad part is that it's the first film of 2012. The only way anybody can sit through is to make fun of it. This movie should be burning in hell where it belongs.F-

With the annoying way too shaky camera, the ridiculous fast-zoom ultra close-ups, and crazy angles I got the worst headache and left the theater within 20 minutes. At one point I was seeing a close-up of an actors neck instead of what could have been beautiful background shots of driving down the street in Rome. The camera man is clearly "non-intelligent" to the extreme, who's "technique" was so distracting, the film is impossible to watch. I sincerely hope this shaky cam stuff comes to an end as I personally can't stand it. It's also unfortunate this horrible release made more than a dime. If you like the idea of driving to a theater, paying cash, and getting yourself a head-banger - this is the film for you.

I'm not one to write reviews, this would be my first actually. But I had to comment because of how brutally disappointed I was. I was very excited to see the movie, as I have loved all the exorcism type movies, and just scary movies in general. But I was really disappointed as due to the EXTREMELY shaky camera work, I couldn't even watch the movie without feeling like I was going to throw up. I ended up keeping my eyes off the screen for probably about 80% of the movie. Besides the extreme motion sickness that it gave me, there was no real climax to the story, and it wasn't scary what so ever. Waste of money in my opinion.

reviews.review_title: Not As Bad As People Say
reviews.content: I sat in the theater and listened to people boo through the last ten minutes and the credits. It won't win an Oscar, no duh. No horror movie will. The Paranormal Activity comparison is odd. One, Paranormal Activity was filmed as more of a "Mock-Home Video" than a "Mockumentary" like The Devil Inside. The ending of Paranormal was more exciting and puzzling because you knew there'd be a sequel. Why a sequel? Because the creators are going to keep taking people's money. This ended because that's the thing: it's The End. No "there goes the demon out the front door to do more carnage." The filming is more stable because, the plot going along with this, an actual cameraman is operating it. Outrageous, I know. Also, it followed along more closely with actual demonology as taught by the church among other beliefs, where as Paranormal Activity was far more fictional and created out of the writer's imagination. I would recommend watching it without high expectations, but don't avoid it just because a bunch of people who can't sit still for an hour and a half and enjoy a good story gave it a bad rating.

This is a realistic review of this movie. I read all of these reviews and am astonished by the amount of hate this movie has received. Its nothing ground breaking and it is your average found footage film. Although I found the concept they implied to be quite original. The mixture of science and religion shown in the film is quite unique. It represents what you might imagine modern exorcists actually doing.The film itself did have its share of scares. I personally find movies of this type to be really scary. Just the thought of this happening to someone is a terrifying thought alone. The execution was good. You are taken into the underworld of Rome. Behind closed doors of stuff that might actually be going on. Yes the plot was not extremely strong but the acting for this type of film wasn't bad at all. I never once lost focus on the movie because of bad acting or seemingly scripted lines.The Ending. I won't give away exactly what happens. The movie throughout does foreshadow this a lot so I saw it coming. A lot of people are complaining and saying it was a terrible way to end the movie. I was expecting something much worse. I will admit there could have been a lot more closure in the ending of this film. There are a lot of things we would have liked to see happen. The ending had a lot of potential to be excellent and I could have thought of about ten better ways to end it. It just so happens though that I am not the director of this film nor the writer. There are plenty of good films with not so good endings. Except it for what it is and just enjoy the movie. Did it make me turn away? Yes. Will I sleep with the light on tonight? More than likely.This is a horror flick and it did its job.

THE DEVIL INSIDE starts out as a promising 'found footage' style mockumentary, detailing demonic possession in much the same way as the (better) LAST EXORCISM. After a genuinely creepy opening segment, however, it gradually starts to fall apart and ends up being an ultra-familiar and, in the end, disappointing movie.The problem with the film is the story, or lack of it. It follows a group of rookie priests who perform various exorcisms, and the narrative is tenuously tied together by the presence of a pretty young woman who's attempting to help her mother, herself a victim of possession. The trouble is, it all plays out exactly as you'd expect, with nary a surprise along the way.It goes without saying that the two exorcism scenes are genuinely disturbing, but that's only because they slavishly copy the EXORCIST formula without adding much in the way of new stuff; it also strikes me that the limb-breaking stuff has been done before in THE LAST EXORCISM or elsewhere. And as the film gets on, it gets worse, until it ends up being just people running around and screaming instead of compelling viewing. It comes up short and abrupt at the end, reinforcing my opinion that the writers ran out of steam.

reviews.review_title: The film features a great car cash, as viewed from inside the car.
reviews.content: The film features a great car cash, as viewed from inside the car. There's some impressive bodily contortions during those possessed moments. Acting is OK, although I found the lead female 'the daughter' to be below par. The film is supposed to look like a documentary filmed by non professional camera personnel, as thus there are far too many moments when the person holding the camera can't hold a camera still for hit. It's way over done. Never once did I feel like I was watching an actual documentary. At that level, the film fails. Also, it's not scary, which is probably why it's Cert 15. The image of the Nun on the DVD cover appears for all of a few seconds during the film?

reviews.review_title: Haven't been this disappointed in a long time (small Spoiler)
reviews.content: I had to just create an account to explain how bad this movie really is. If you have seen the preview for this "movie" if thats even what you want to call it, then you have seen everything you need to see. I guess it is my fault for actually believing this was going to be different than any other exorcism movie. I wont lie, I get scared pretty easily at movies, and this film didn't even make me flinch in the theater. I sat behind a boy that had to be no more than 9 years-old, "Dad this movie was stupid" was his quote at the end of the movie. Speaking of was not a thrilling conclusion leaving me wanting more. I called the ending before the movie was even over, a big event (in this case a car crash)and then a statement saying they were never found. Overall poorly made, poorly directed, not worth a dollar on red box. Maybe if there wasn't so much hype it would have appeared better. If you truly need to see it watch the 2 min 30sec trailer for 89min.

reviews.review_title: A truly gripping and interesting film....
reviews.content: I think some of the reviews i have read are harsh, if you were not wanting a documentary style film then why on earth did you watch it... no maybe it isn't as scary as some make it out to be, or as it even claimed to be. But the STORY is brilliant, it is a story that even weeks after watching you will still be trying to figure out... it all starts well, and gets straight in.... and then yes there i some slow periods but it builds up to some great moments.If you love exorcism movies then it would be a brilliant film to add to your collection, if you love horror films then again its a good one to add to the collection.The director uses a superb blend of science and religion to get the believable storyline across, and to truly haunt the viewers that night.It is well worth a watch!

What a God-awful pile of crap this was. And that's coming from a huge fan of mockumentary/found footage films. The Devil Inside follows a a young woman trying to discover why her mum killed three people during an exorcism. She teams up with two rogue priests that perform exorcisms outside of the church's jurisdiction. What makes this film so bad? Mostly it's how unconvincing it is as a documentary. Why bother with this facade if you are completely moronic when it comes to documentaries? WIthin the first 20 minutes we see a number of instances that break the film's own rules. First of all the girl starts asking about the cameras in the car. No documentary would include this moment, it's just an example of a fake documentary reminding you of what it's supposed to be. Next, a doctor walks down a doctor sneaks up on the protagonist with no sounds of footsteps, a second later he starts walking and yes, we hear footsteps again. Then we have a set-up in a room where we see CCTV and no cameraman, and suddenly footage from the cameraman's perspective. Is he invisible? Does he run in and out of the room? Hell if I know. It gets no better with the awful performances and idiotic characters. They act as though this is a normal scripted narrative, and forget to be real. I'm guessing zero amount of improvisation went into this film. Later we also see blood splat on the camera lens and then it vanishes. It isn't wiped away, it just disappears. Finally we get to the end. Well, actually we don't. There is no end to this film. It just finishes and gives you a website link to "read up on the case". Would you like to do that once you've wasted your money? No, didn't think so. Make sure this film dies a horrible and painful death. It truly is disgusting, and doesn't even bother to try and entertain. When the most enjoyable part of the movie involves the attempted drowning of a baby and the audience wishes they were the baby, then you don't deserve to make films.

reviews.review_title: Why all the bad reviews? I thought it was good
reviews.content: When I first saw the trailer, I did think 'Oh great, exorcism again! Been used so many times' but then it was mentioned about multiple demonic possession, which was new to me. I was then so excited to see it. I then read the rating and the reviews of saying how bad it was. My expectations then lowered. But I thought 'I still want to see what I think' I went to see it and came out pleasantly surprised.The story was intriguing and captivating. OK, I admit, some ideas have been used before, for example, the demon passing on to someone else (Fallen, with Denzel Washinton, great film) The acting was very good, especially from the mother. I'm also really glad about the decreased voice effects from the demon which made it more realistic.The ending I did think was a bit rubbish, but it didn't ruin it for me.So go and see it by all means and go with an open mind. See what you think. Wouldn't say it's the scariest but it's still enjoyable.

The Devil Inside (2012): Dir: William Brent Bell / Dir: Fernanda Andrade, Simon Quarterman, Evan Helmuth, Suzan Crowley, Bonnie Morgan: Here is yet another nauseating so-called true story marketing ploy that shakes the camera about to the point where throwing up on the movie screen would improve the picture. It is a lame supernatural thriller about the presence of evil, such as the way they market this crap. It begins with promise featuring a 911 call where an apparent exorcism concluded with several dead bodies. Now the possessed is in Italy or Rome, or some bloody place where they shacked her up in a rubber room, and her dimwitted daughter decides to document her visit after twenty years. This cannot end well for these morons nor the audience who has to sit through it. Director William Brent Bell strikes up tremendous images of Rome and Italy and such but he cannot save the actors from themselves. When Fernanda Andrade, who plays the daughter, becomes possessed, any so-called true story account goes straight down the shitter with any other brilliant logic the screenwriter concocted during a night of heavy drinking. There are two pea brain Priests, one who becomes possessed and attempts to drown a baby during a baptism. Then there is the mother who cuts herself and likely removed herself from any Mother's Day card delivery. Either that or she just became so upset at this career move that she attempts suicide to remove the embarrassment. We witness the twitching and distorted possessed bodies who are in such agony, nobody is in more agony than the poor saps viewing its spectacle. Score: 4 / 10

reviews.review_title: Painfully below average story of possession
reviews.content: TL;DR: Don't even bother. You've seen it all before. If you've seen the trailer, you've seen the whole movie.It feels like the creators of this one weren't even trying to make it stand out. There are absolutely no original ideas or even tense moments. This is filled with tired cliches that we have seen over and over again.And to make matters worse, the execution of these cliches doesn't even make par. There is no build up, no tension, no scares. Events just kind of happen and move along to the next set piece (where essentially the same thing will happen in a different room).By the end of the first 30 minutes, you've practically seen the whole film. Cliched religious chanting happens over and over and over without much variation in delivery, effect, or outcome. It becomes irritating fast.This was incredibly dull and unimaginative. I wish I hadn't even bothered with it. I've seen films that were filmed for less than $500 that were more creative and effective than this wet fart.

WTF is This Mess? Shot in "documentary" shaky camera style footage - but really a bad home movie. So awful I had to keep fast-forwarding to try to find a decent part - there isn't any. The lead actress's role is that of the daughter of the possessed woman and this daughter acts like she's really doing something - like she's Miss It. Irky! The possessed mother is too stupid to be called campy. The so-called priests are junk - they don't act remotely like a real priest.This is completely garbage. Find a half-way decent film to watch instead of this tripe.1/10.

"An exorcism is tantamount to a miracle - an extraordinary intervention of God." Gabriele NanniAs a fallen down, Catholic-trained moviegoer, I am still in awe of the papacy, the Basilica, and priests in general. I will have to say if the pope didn't sanction the exorcisms in The Devil Within, then he is right for a change. It is possession porn ripped right out of the frames of The Exorcist, Blair Witch, The Rite, and Paranormal Activity. Like last summer's The Last Exorcism, it's a found footage, faux documentary, demon drama, this time about a young woman, Isabella Rossi (Fernanda Andrade), who goes to Italy to find her mother, Maria (Suzan Crowley), who was placed in Rome's Centrino Hospital for the Criminally Insane (I don't know why there and probably nobody else knows) after she allegedly murdered three people during her own exorcism.The series of unauthorized exorcisms Isabella becomes involved in to understand her mother's crime are boilerplate movie mosh ups using the same foul language ("The pig is mine!"), the same rude force hurtling people around the room, and no resolution or understanding of what forces are at work here, beyond the bland "devil."If you must see this drivel, you must stay until the end to see one of the lamest conclusions ever in film. Come to think of it, we may be hard pressed to find another film this bad the entire year of 2012. "It is precisely our job as Catholics to speak the truth as plainly and precisely as we can." Sargent Shriver

reviews.review_title: Very boring and not creative at all exorcism movie
reviews.content: Wow, I heard some positive reviews so decided to check this movie out and for the most part it was a waste of time. In fact most of the audiences couldn't sit still constantly fidgeting including me. I just couldn't see how anyone could give this movie positive reviews. I had some expectation for this movie and it was a bust. I was expecting something along the lines of "The Last Exorcism" which I found to be entertaining at least. That just isn't the case for this movie. For a found footage movie this just isn't believable at all and it tries to go in a direction like the stuff that happened on camera really happened. The beginning it starts out slightly creepy but than on majority of the way through is boring stuff constantly. People just rambling on about exorcism and it isn't anything new, interesting or innovative. In fact after just few minutes in I saw couple of audiences leave which was actually a smart move. I never left during a movie in a theater yet, but was close to doing it. The research they done for this movie was off and ridiculous which is fine for some movies but they try to go in a direction like this really happened which makes it not work. I won't even bother talking about the plot cause there really isn't much to it at all. To put it simply a women is mentally unstable or possessed and kills three people and end up in a mental asylum. Than her daughter does a documentary with two priest and a camera man on exorcism. The character decisions in this movie doesn't make much sense and the acting gets a bit too over the top and dramatic. Simon Quarterman who I saw for the first time was alright and the exorcism scenes was creepy and even a bit eerie although it's very few. The priests in this movie bash the Vatican church system but they smoke and swear, which might work if this is going in the similar direction as "Constantine" or "Dylan Dog" it might have worked. But for a movie like this nothing really works. I am so glad this movie isn't long and there will be no controversy with the Vatican church over this movie. The ending will also probably tick some audiences off, if anyone can even call it a ending. It just builds to the main point and ends.3.3/10

reviews.review_title: Worth watching, at least at home
reviews.content: Overall - I liked it. Several scenes in the movie did give me the creeps, they were nicely done. The story is quite engaging and authors could've squeezed way more nice scenes and way better ending than they did. So here it is - the only grudge against the movie I have is a very weak, abrupt ending. The flow of the story suggests that the sweetest part of the whole masquerade is coming... and it just ends, leaving a bunch of unanswered questions, and a whole bunch of killed expectations.And of course you must like movies like Paranormal Activity, to enjoy this one.

The Devil Inside is a brilliant horror film. It's based on a young woman who wants to find out what happened at her mothers exorcism, in which she is taken into the world of people haunted by the spirits themselves. It is honestly a brilliant film, the ending is really good; regardless of what people have to say as it ends on a cliffhanger. The infrequant gory moments are very disturbing. The images of the dead people are in fact probably the most horrifying I've ever scene on a Horror Film since 2008, this is what makes it one of the best horror films ever to be made. It's worth the £10.00 and it's worth waiting for the torrent to download. It is a truly sensational film and very scary. It takes a lot for me to say this but it is 1 of the most disturbing films since The Exorcist and it fits in increasingly well with the genre. Trust me, it's worth every penny.

reviews.review_title: The Devil Inside needs to be exorcised at least 127 times.
reviews.content: The seed that grew into January being a "dump month" for horror films, a term used to describe the releasing of low quality studio productions. The first weekend of January now being the most infamous time of release for typically the worst horror film of the year. The Devil Inside was that film for 2012. Except, it wasn't just the worst horror film of the year, it was the worst film period. What. Even. Was. This!? A woman investigates her mother's murder spree twenty years ago, when she soon becomes involved in a series of exorcisms. I...I can't quite describe how diabolical this generic piece of rubbish is. It honestly achieved the unachievable. A horror film so tame, that it made Miley Cyrus' smash hit "Can't Be Tamed" ironically less tame. A creation so lacklustre, that I myself wished I was possessed by a demon, so that they could watch this atrocity instead of me. A production so derivative, that it will leave you gasping for air, not due to fear, but because you are suffocating yourself in an attempt to end this nightmare. Yes, asphyxiation is the only solution, I said it. It seriously encompasses every modern horror trope, from standard formulaic exorcisms to the found footage style narrative. Brent Bell's choppy directing and lifeless approach hindered the cast's performances which were dull to say the least. Jump scares were infrequent (yay!) and calming (nay!) with the entire plot being a predictable bore. A script so dire that, I kid you not, there was a line that compared an exorcist to Superman. Sure. I'll bite. Let's see if a member of the church can withstand a bullet to the head, that'll raise a religious outcry. I mean, what a stupid thing to say! But that's not all, ohhhh no. I saved the best til last. The ending. A conclusion that conjures up so much disdain from critics and audiences that it was rated one of the worst endings ever. Damn right! Absolutely nothing about the case was answered, it just...ended. Then they show a website you can access to keep track of the case!? No. You know what? I'm done.

The first time I saw the trailer for this film I laughed out loud because of how bad it looked, and I wasn't wrong. This film is just another generic exorcism movie, like all those crappy ones you see on Net-Flix. The most frightening thing about this film is how much money it made, it is so bad, but people love this stuff for some reason.The plot was nothing new, and the characters were bland as usual in these types of films. The exorcism scenes were nothing to be afraid of, there was plenty of contorted movements and levitation. The found footage did not help this film at all, the only time it worked was during the beginning police crime scene. This film was so boring I fast forwarded through most of the dialogue. Someone sitting in front of a camera, trying to act, for five minutes straight is pushing the limit.This film is awful and should be buried away somewhere, films like this should not be mainstream, there are a lot more films that were more well done than this, but received much less, but most people don't care about the movie being good, they just want mind numbing generic crap. I do not recommend this film, and I never will.

reviews.review_title: Good enough to see, leaves much to be desired.
reviews.content: Heading into this film I expected an experience similar to The Exorcism of Emily Rose, or The Exorcist, based upon the marketing campaign and what was shown in trailers.What I saw was much different.This film is shot and plotted in a style similar to Paranormal Activity.The audience is introduced to Isabella Rossi, a non-relatable, bland character who's mother is presumed to be possessed. She lacked a lot in character depth, and the film did not deal with the existential questions she might have about her future, the future of her mother, and her family. The facade of a "documentary" is easily broken after about two or three scenes featuring Isabella, as her believability and presence are akin to those of a poorly written fan- fiction character, possibly even worse. The main selling point for most when it comes to The Devil Inside is the actual scenes from the exorcisms and activity of the possessed. Which, in fairness, was pretty much the only good part of the film. There were only three scenes featuring Maria Rossi, Isabella's mother, whose possession seemed, at first, to be the central plot of the film, but she is never revisited after one attempt at exorcism.There is more "intrigue" about two priests who are "vigilante exorcists" and who are performing exorcisms against the will of the Vatican. I found this idea laughable, and somewhat clever at best. It made the film even less believable and these character's presences made the others even less relatable because of their unrealistic reactions to the various dangerous, and frankly traumatic situations the priests get the protagonists into.Although this film contains one of the most graphic suicide scenes I've seen to date, which may intrigue some people. In summation (tl;dr) crappy Paranormal Activity with fewer ghosts and more priests, poorly written and developed characters, many loose ends, and an attempt at an ending that would make viewers think, but ultimately just made the film worse.

How stupid is this film? The plot centers on the Vatican School of Exorcism where all classes are apparently held in English. Every single moment of this film that comes close to working is just stolen from "The Exorcist". This movie ends with a title card that implies that nobody knows what REALLY happened ... but we just saw what happened ... it's a found footage film guys ... oh, whatever. Idiots.

Now I wanted to come up with a clever title but realising that the moment you put something along he lines of 'OMG 2 hours of my life back please' as your title it just makes you seem like the most elitest **** ever.Lets talk about the big thing first, it's not scary. Some may say thats subjective but honestly, people don't seem to get the fact that waiting for something to go bang and being scary are not the same thing. They both make you feel tense but waiting for the next loud noise to come never unnerves you, makes you feel vulnerable or lets your imagination do anything apart from wonder what form the next 'boo' was coming.That being said there were 2 moments in which the film actually remembered it was a horror instead of being a succession of party poppers being let off at random intervals. First was the 'Connect the cuts' moments as seen in the trailer which managed to be unnerving but was handling the rest of that scene so badly it almost stooped into the realms of comedy.The second was the scene after the baptism (no spoilers) where there was a genuine sense of overhanging dread before and after the big bang came. That would have meant nothing to you if you haven't seen the film but, in short, there are two relatively scary moments in the film and the rest borders on comical in how hard it tries to creep the audience out.A film trying this hard to be realistic, what with the real world setting, the faux documentary style etc is always make or break in the acting department. You know where this is going. The acting isn't exceptionally bad but rather uninspiring and completely devoid of enthusiasm no matter how many times each character gets thrown across a room or cries. You would think that after witnessing an actual demon be extracted from someone that it would leave a lasting impression on the sceptical protagonist. Maybe she would start to doubt and re-evaluate everything she has taken for granted until now? If there are demons could there be such thing as ghosts? Aliens? How much do we really matter in the overall scheme of things if these higher powers actually exist? Are we really disposable pawns in the overall battle between good and evil?Well you and I know what I'm getting at so I'll just end this by saying that about five minutes after the encounter she is looking over the recorded footage making passing judgement about the size of the victims pupils with the futility of someone commenting on a picture of Jesus's crusty face on the bottom of a senile ladies frying pan in on their local magazine.The ending is bad. A woeful cop-out 'to be continued' but never will be because of how bad the film is ending pretty much sums it up. Abrupt and so completely out of nowhere in an attempt to be shocking that as the credits rolled, someone in the audience of about 10 people on a Wednesday afternoon including me and a friend actually stood up and said "really?" which led to a greater emotional outburst from the audience than anything the film achieved.The worst thing? I almost fell asleep during the first exorcism. That isn't some snarky brandy swilling, egotistical, made up want to be criticy talk no, I'm dead serious I was nodding of during an exorcism that lasted about 10 minutes but seemed about 30. If thats not a testament to this films failings I don't know what is.The devil inside is either as dull as a powerpoint presentation assembled by a fumbling old history teacher who can't get the projector to work and so has to call one of the school 'techies' to stop him from rubbing the projector with oil, or merely average. the kindest thing you can say is that at least half of this film can be described as the latter.

reviews.review_title: Great if you're into exorcisms, not so much if you're looking for a big scare
reviews.content: While this movie isn't anywhere close to the intense, heart-wrenching, horrifying, and goose-bump-inducing movie "The Exorcist", it still has a place in the exorcist movie world.I really think they went in the right direction when they decided to make it a documentary-type way of filming (much like the Paranormal Activity series). I think it really helps to add to the realism.Now on the other hand, I would NOT recommend this movie to anyone who is looking for a really big scare. It never gave me that intense and heart-wrenching feeling that I got while watching movies like "The Exorcist" and "Paranormal Activity". It kind of seems to just beat around the bush the entire movie, in a sense.The worst part of the entire movie, in my opinion, was the ending. After the movie was over, I had a feeling of absolute emptiness. They could have, at the very least, showed what happened to Maria Rossi. Did the demon really leave her? Was she back to normal? Did they survive the car accident? Yes, I'm sure many people are saying "Well it was a creative and non-cliché ending". While that may be true, you can make a creative ending without leaving so much out. This was probably the worst ending I've ever seen in a movie that started with so much potential. I just felt I never got that really enormous scare that I was waiting for.The bottom line, this movie has so much potential, but I feel it never fully utilizes it, and in the end you leave feeling empty. On the other hand, it does have some really cool information on exorcisms, and some really awesome acting to go with it. There were some really dramatic and intense scenes. I really felt like they were really in that situation and that they weren't even acting at all. Not to mention the way it was presented was really top-notch. Like I said, this movie has a ton of potential, but it seems to just simply fizzle out. I believe it can be enjoyed non-the-less. Although if you want to get a scare out of it, I suggest watching it alone!

reviews.review_title: Decent horror movie with a few genuinely scary moments
reviews.content: Exorcism films have been done to death. As have found footage films. So I wasn't expecting much from this film, but I decided to go just to see if the two genres would work together. Surprisingly, this movie wasn't bad. It was actually a pretty entertaining little movie, and I found myself actually getting scared at some points. There's an extremely tense scene between Isabella and her mother that will have you on edge the whole time, and while the ending was much loathed by the group of friends I went with, I thought it was a clever ending. Predictable, but clever nonetheless. The film takes a little bit to get going, but when it does it brings you in and if you view it with an open mind, it might actually scare you. A decent blend of the exorcism and found footage subgenres, I recommend this to anyone that's just looking for some creepy entertainment and not too much more.Overall : 6.5/10

OK...i do not often go to see a movie that takes such a low rank from IMDb. I saw Devil inside yesterday... 3.6? i mean ..you are nor serous. Blackwater Valley Exorcism ( a total parody) takes 3.6. This movie deserves better. It is not a great movie. Do not expect to see anything new. It's like a combo of "The Rite" and "The Last Exorcism" . But i don't have problems to see same thing in such matters. I mean when i watch a movie with zombies i expect to see dead mean walking slow with their hands in front, and when i watch a movie with vampires i expect people drinking blood to survive. What do you expect in an exorcism movie? Twisted ankles and bad male voice coming from a girl and furniture moving. That's what you get .. fair deal for me. So it is a 6. Not a very good movie but much better from "The woman in black" i say last. The truth is i don;t remember when was the last time i saw a really good horror movie..

reviews.review_title: Ticks all the cliché boxes of a 'found-footage' horror.
reviews.content: If you're an amateur film-goer like myself and you are keen on a simple scare, then the trailer will have dragged you into the cinema for the first viewing of this 'found-footage' first person experience!One of the first things that sprung to mind within the first five minutes of the film was how let down I was with the acting. Now I know it's become 'the thing' to make a 'found-footage' film or a documentary type horror (Paranormal Activity, Fourth Kind, Blair Witch), but if that's the case, then at least make the acting good enough to be believable! If it's a documentary, I don't want to see people creating seconds of suspense between their sentences to each other; this film made me cringe inside at the use of this exactly. Within the first 20 minutes of the film, after a couple of 'jumps', my girlfriend asked me 'Is this real?', I simply replied 'No, look at the acting. You can tell.', to me, it was that simple.I won't be all negative about the film, they had a fairly good storyline to keep up with, they had the effects and such thrown in the right places, however, it seems clear they got carried away with the 'lets see what we can do to make the audience jump' thing, considering this was meant to be a documentary. Walking down the path, out of nowhere, a dog appears and barks at the cast, coincidence for a 'footage' film? I think not and I know it's acting, but the distance between reality and acting grew at this point when all but the cameraman seemed to be scared.****SPOILERS****Here, I'll point out some things I noticed that made it clear to me that this film was definitely more acting than reality and a lot more of 'let's make the audience focus elsewhere for suspense..'(.. despite the fact it's a documentary), firstly, I'll start with the Baptism scene.. what does this have to do with the rest of the film at all? It doesn't, it's there just to add suspense and branch another story off the already fake one. Which is why I knew, as soon as they cut to that scene that something was going to happen, straight away. Okay another one, when Isabella is talking to the camera about Michael, something about 'I wish I could turn this around on him', I instantly noticed half of the screen was facing behind her and the other half was catching what she was saying, now call me psychic, but I predicted something was going to happen behind her and guess what.. it did. If this was a documentary, the character's would've never have focused more on the camera angle where something is about to happen or something that seems completely off the storyline unless you know something's going to happen.. Maybe I'm just being picky? Let's go back to the storyline....So the film builds up, the cast go to Italy, exorcisms happen, people get possessed, see the odd couple of graphic scenes that get your heart beating.. sounding good, yeah? Imagine the film stopping there. Oh wait, it does. If you've read any reviews already, based on the ending, you'll probably know what I'm going to say.. So, the film builds up and you're thinking 'Shit, I wonder what's going to happen!?', well apparently, a typical 'all-cast death' happens, that made the guy behind me comfortably shout 'Fuck off!' when the credits hit. I know this is going to sound typical of me to say, but I saw it coming (okay, not exactly, but hear me out..), during the ending car scene, I noticed that anytime the camera view from the back, facing to the front, had blurred out the characters in view and left only the view through the windshield clear. This to me, instantly said 'something's either going to jump out in front of the car or something's going to happen to the car.', again.. typical of a footage film? Not in my opinion.I'll stop there. If you're in for a cliché film based on 'footage', and basically want to see all the typical things that always happen in these type of films where the ending is terrible.. yeah, I'd advise you watch this.

Devil Inside, The (2012) ** (out of 4) Isabella (Fernanda Andrade) and a documentary filmmaker travel to Italy where they want to find out what really happened twenty years earlier when her mother killed three people supposedly during an exorcism. Along with the help of a couple priests Isabella plans on finding out if exorcism are real and if her mother was ever possessed. THE DEVIL INSIDE is yet another film showing off the "found footage" format and I think the entire genre has almost ran its course. I'm not going to call this one of the worst horror films ever made as many have. I'm not going to call the ending one of the worst in the history of cinema like many have. THE DEVIL INSIDE isn't a horrid film or a good one and what really makes me upset at it is how bland and lifeless it is. If you've ever seen a horror movie in your life then you're going to know all the tricks here. This includes quiet moments where the surround sound gets a workout with one of those fake scares from a loud noise. You're going to know when the characters are all gathered around talking while the "subject" is calm that the person will then go crazy to try and get another fake scare. The problem is that these fake scares don't even work and the execution of the film really isn't all that impressive. If the fake scares don't work then you know the real ones aren't going to either. I found the film lacking any real atmosphere and I'd say that the entire exorcism plot line is just played out. Nothing fresh or original happens here and it's really not too hard to catch the twist that happens at the end. I will say that I did enjoy the performances with Andrade doing a fine job in the lead. Supporting players Simon Quarterman and Evan Helmuth are also good. THE DEVIL INSIDE is far from being a horrible movie but it's somewhat worse simply because it's bland. At least with bad movies you can have fun with them and that's certainly not the case here.

reviews.review_title: If you like horror because you are chasing the next scare.....you won't find it here!
reviews.content: OK so I love horror for the reason that I enjoy being scared out of my wits! How do I know this film wasn't scary? I didn't turn each and every light on on the way to the toilet after watching it! I won't be lay in bed this evening thinking about this film. This is hard for me to say because I am very much a strong advocate of all horror films, the genre in general! I hate to speak negatively of horror but this film had about as much horror as Toy Story! It's just not scary at all! If you are a TRUE horror fan you WILL watch this as I did purely for the fact that true horror fans will watch any horror film they can get their hands on. Especially exorcism films. This film is lagging way way behind other pretty dire exorcism films such as Exorcism of Emily Rose, The Last Exorcism and Exorcisms! In my opinion, however humble, this film was worse than those! It tried to rip every other exorcism film off and failed.I won't say 'don't watch it' because your going to anyway and I WISH I could have rated this film better, I waited SO long for it and was extremely looking forward to watching it. I was let down. I hope you find the film more pleasing than I did, some people are as per other reviews.1 out of 10 - Sorry!

reviews.review_title: Cinema Blue Balls: The Devil Inside Can't Come
reviews.content: Why is this movie so bad? Why the outrage? While the movie's trailers portrays foreboding eerie exorcism sequences and the following of Isabella, the main protagonist, what the audience is actually presented with is a scattered focus with no real main character development, and minor disturbing exorcism scenes. Lack of character development inherently draws apathy from movie goers. The supposed scary scenes are not much in comparison with many other movies of the horror genre.However, the main disappointment, is right at the climax of the film, which I shan't spoil for any potential viewers. The audience is abruptly hit with the movie's ending, which leaves very much to be desired. It is as if the structure of the story's beginning, rising action, and climax (yes I said 'climax') is there, but the writer completely forgot the resolution part of what comprises a story. This left the audience in my theater booing and demanding refunds. There was no explanation to what happened, no resolution to the characters' fates.

OK. Clever. Taking the mick out of "hand held" films. I recognised the priests were actors, so soon figured out it wasn't a true documentary or "inspired" by true events.Plenty of nods toward The Exorcist with similar dialogue by the "possessed". So this film is not to be taken seriously.Although set in Rome, half the cast were speaking English or "pigeon" Italian, so it dawned on you that this film was, I imagine, a satire on the "hand held" film genre.However, I still felt drawn in by the film which I feel is a positive of the "hand held" because you think you are watching real events unfold. Maybe, you get the feeling that the genre has outlived its interest value, which in fact is timely for this film.3.6 is too low as a rating and in light of the foregoing it should receive at least a 7. Notwithstanding how the film finished which a lot of people would have issues with.

Apparently exorcism movies and paranormal entities have become a pop phenomena among the horror business these past few years. The Last Exorcism, The Exorcism of Emily Rose, it seems like a good idea to bare away from the central exorcism movie sometimes, like The Rite, and it might be a good outcome. Unfortunately, Anthony Hopkins is not here to carry this dull-bulbed snoozer.The Devil Inside is about a woman who has questionably become possessed by several entities, and is succumbed to a plethora of exorcisms relating to murders that happened. The problem that lies within TDI, is that there is no character development, no sense of danger/thrill from the cheap effects and lame scares. Like they did not really try at all and just figured people would enjoy it anyway. The story sinks about 30 minutes in and veers off in twenty different ways, and the movie ultimately becomes unappealing, incredibly boring and hard to follow. The scenes that are supposed to shock or put the audience in suspense left me laughing, and just when I thought the movie was going to redeem itself a little or show some sense of professionalism, it's ruined.Leave this one alone folks. You're better off watching the original The Exorcist, or something else in a $5 bin...

reviews.review_title: Pirate this movie and you'll still feel ripped off
reviews.content: I just came back from opening night. I can't believe that I wasted my Friday night on this trash. The commercials didn't make it look like the typical shaky cam third person movie. Everything you saw in the commercials was everything good in the movie, but at least the commercials showed them all at once. Rather than having you sit through boring dribble between each. Basically it was your typical shaky cam, and poorly acted, movie with a few cliché and overused parlor tricks. It amazed me how a studio can rip people off like this and then scratch their heads and complain about people pirating their movies. Maybe if they didn't rip us off, we wouldn't feel the need to rip them off.

The subject of possession is one of the most heated and debated topics of our time. Can demons seize control over humans, thereby causing great suffering to both themselves and everyone around them, or is it just mental illness? The Catholic Church would have you believe that latter, but let's face it; some things just cannot be explained, and if there is no such thing as demonic possession, why even train exorcists? Paramount Insurge's new film The Devil Inside tackles these questions while delivering some genuine scares to kick off the new year.It all starts with a chilling phone call to police placed by a woman named Maria Rossi (Crowley). She alerts the authorities that she has slain three people. Upon arriving at her home, the police discover a massacre, and once Rossi is in custody, it becomes really apparent that she's not your ordinary killer. Something is just ... off.
