reviews.review_title: Found Documentary Footage Approach to Exorcism
reviews.content: I watched "The Devil Inside" without seeing the trailer. From the first frame, it already tells us that it would play out like a documentary about Exorcisms, unauthorized by the Catholic Church. Aha! Another found-footage film in the tradition of "Blair Witch" and "Paranormal Activity."Like those other two aforementioned films, the build up of the action was very slow. This film follows Isabella Rossi (Fernanda Andrade) as she investigates how to help her mother Maria (Suzan Crowley), who had been locked in a mental institution in Italy after she killed three religious personnel who were apparently in the process of exorcising her. The first 30 minutes or so were spent as a rather pedantic discussion about exorcism. When the investigator goes with a young exorcist Fr. Ben (Simon Quarterman) to an actual exorcism, that is when the film becomes interesting. The team encounters Maria only by the first hour already. The last 15 minutes were an unexpectedly bizarre turn of events which unfortunately end as soon as they were built up. I don't know how to rate this film. Maybe there is only so much that can be done about exorcism in film, and there had certainly been so many already, almost every year. "The Devil Inside" at least tries to be different with a serious documentary approach to the events. It is not as bad as reviews would have you believe. The bad reviews may actually be good for you as they would temper your expectations, and make you like this film more.

reviews.review_title: True Life: My Mom is Possessed by the Devil.
reviews.content: Written by Markus Robinson, Edited by Nicole Ashland Who is William Brent Bell? Could he be the director of the new low budget exorcism movie "The Devil Inside"? Could he be the man to single handedly spell the end for these faux-documentary "horror" movies? Could he also be the director of the first bad movie of the year? In the end, WHO CARES who William Brent Bell is! Because whatever far too negative thoughts which come to mind when the term "director" and William Brent Bell are used in the same sentence, will soon become as irrelevant as his career is after directing "The Devil Inside".Though the trailers promises audiences an entertaining horror movie full of scares and terrifying images, due to a grocery list of outstanding flaws "The Devil Inside" is doomed to snatch the title of worst film of 2012 so far (and it's only the second week!). The faults are as follows: Via an awful script, this film attempts to become far deeper than simply a B movie horror flick, by inserting psychological dialogues having to do with mental health disorders as the modern Catholic Church's alternative to possession, which does nothing but slow the film down to a crawl (at times). The script (partially written by Bell himself) also does its part to take away from any scary moments the film would have had. Any time there was a genuine build up to a scare, one of the characters would say something utterly outlandish or begin singing "The Itsy Bitsy Spider" and create a state of unintentional goofiness that worked to negate any and all scares. The acting also hinders this movie greatly. The phrase "can't act his/her way out of a paper bag" cannot be used enough in this case, but that is to be expected out of a low-budget film of this nature. Furthermore, if there were any dust particles of entertainment value floating aimlessly throughout this film, they were overshadowed by some inexcusably shaky camera-work which was so bad that while watching the film I realized (beyond a shadow of a doubt) that "The Devil Inside" stood alone as the worst visual experience I have ever had watching a hand held faux-documentary. The phrase "Can't direct his way out of a paper bag" can also be thrown around quite liberally here, as the director of this amateurish endeavor shows his lack of skills early and often. There are some scenes were the camera (mid-sentence) cuts to inconceivable shots of the side of a forehead and others (when cameras are installed in a car) that look as if everybody's mouths and body movements were inexplicably sped up post-production. There is also a directorial ploy used where (from time to time throughout the film) the cameraman pulls priests and other characters of note into "confessionals" of sorts where they spout off emotionally driven asides of how they are really scared or how they don't like the other people in the house. Yes, these scenes are all too stupidly reminiscent of similarly shot sequences in MTV shows such as "The Real World" or "Jersey Shore". But all the bad acting, lazy camera-work, sloppy dialogue and the fact that the first hour of this "horror film" contains a debilitatingly slow build up, with little to no actual scares in it, can all be forgiven and considered side effects of hokey B movie productions. BUT, what cannot be forgiven is the slap in the face ending, which consists of a half-way descent climax culminating in basically (SPOILER ALERT) an abrupt ending. And as the groans from the audience commenced as the screen suddenly goes black (an ending that is all too egregiously overused in films like these), a message flashes on the screen ballsy enough to incite a riot. It reads: For more information about this case, go to www.mariarossi.com (or something to that effect). To me this is the equivalent to watching a Discovery Channel show and being told "for more information on tigers consult your local library". In short, while it works for said Discovery Channel show, what did I just pay for?! Did I really just pay 10.50 to see a movie that contains, not an actual ending, but a climax which results in a website where I am to continue to seek out an ending that the director refused to show in theaters?! Another way to see this ending could be as Bell letting the audiences know (in so many words) how he already has their money, therefore he can throw any old ending up there and nobody could stop him. To quote the Comic Book Guy from The Simpsons, "Worst ending ever!" Final Thought: I am not going to lie. For about fifteen minutes of this 87 minute film (beginning around minute 60) there is a semblance of suspense that, no matter how predictable, was somewhat engaging. BUT the fact that it took so long to get to this point in conjunction with the sad fact of how it ended (my God, don't get me started again on that ending) negates almost any recollection of entertainment value "The Devil Inside" had. So obviously my consensus is to skip "The Devil Inside", unless you are a fan of sitting through movies where you can barely see anything that is happening on screen; or crappy endings.Please visit my page on Examiner.com http://www.examiner.com/x-52464-San-Jose-Indie-Movie-Examiner and leave any comments you have about this or any review. The more hits I get the better. Thank you.Follow me on Twitter @moviesmarkus

After the insistence of some friends of mine to see this picture, I saw no other thing to do, but give it a try. When people told me this movie would involve exorcisms and Catholic church, I thought they wouldn't be so lazy and would make a new story for this genre-- how naive I am. The first part of the movie is basically the same as "The Rite"; a school of priests in Rome and one of the students not believing anything he's been taught. Other than that, the film is a completely rip off of some mainstream movies, such as "The Exorcist", "Paranormal Activity", "Exorcism of Emily Rose", among others. I have to admit some scenes are a little frightening, specially with that woman screaming all of a sudden and making me jump out of the cinema's seat. Also, I can't deny Suzan Crowley is good; that first scene when her daughter went to visit her proves that-- even thought I indeed LAUGHED in that scene because I find crazy people really funny. But the hugest complaint of mine is the disappointing ending, which I believe NOBODY will enjoy! Avoid this film and stuck with the old versions of this saturated subject.

To my disappointment this is very average. Am sure it would be more enjoyable if I had never seen an exorcism movie before or had never seen the demon switch bodies format of Fallen etc. The acting however is okay and the only reason I have given it a 4 rather than less. The idea itself is sound although would have been better if it had not been so obvious. The fact that the plot is centred on the fact that the Vatican was able to take an American woman who had committed multiple murder to Italy and commit her there was laughable. Am sure she would be locked up in an American high security mental unit far less able to leave the country. In addition, there is nowhere near enough actual exorcism footage. The protagonists are very easily convinced at the existence of the devil etc. Also the lack of consistency of the characterisation of the practising priest who is doing undercover exorcisms but doesn't let it bother him until this one is ridiculous. And the ending views like a teenage horror story: the writer has no idea how to end it so kills everyone. One step away from 'it was all a dream'. A film for the inexperienced watchers am afraid.

I can't believe this is the movie starting off my new year. Geez, I hope it's not a bad omen of the films to come. Than again it is the craptastic month of January one of the two months of the year(the other being September) where they release their throwaway films. Made for less than a million dollars by a company named Insurge films that I've never heard of "The Devil Inside" is a boring, generic rehash of horror clichés with a lot of imagination but left effectless by bad performances, confused direction and well tiresome horror clichés. The film tells the tale of a young woman who comes to Rome to visit her mother in a mental hospital. After not having seen her the better portion of her life. Because she was committed there after she murdered three people while they were performing an exorcism on her. Of course the daughter arrives with a cameraman to document the experience and she discovers her mother is indeed possessed. With the help of two priests who conduct unapproved exorcisms she is invited to attend exorcisms so that she may better understand her mothers situation. The big problem with this film above all others even though it has many, Is that it's not believable in the least. Their are such huge gaps in the logic of the film that leave you feeling confused. Such as the fact that we are supposed to believe that they would commit her to a mental institution in Rome despite the fact that she lives in America or that anyone would think it would be a good idea for someone to tag along for exorcisms or that any of the characters in this film could gain any type of authority to visit any of these places or conduct any of the situations that appear on film. Most notably the exorcism of her mother in a different hospital room than in which the one she stays, and there are many many more. None of the performances are very effective, the characters are not well drawn, the film making feels shorted, the spfx look cheesy and there are really no scares. All of which is sad because the film has moments where you can see the potential it has of becoming a much better film. Had they further developed the characters and story lines which in tail would have heightened the films suspense level and made the film more effective overall they could have really hit something great with this concept. Instead what we are left with is a mishmash of sordid horror clichés and stolen scenes from much better films that would have served better had they been re-released in their original counterparts. That being said I'm a big fan of the found footage film and it's very rare that I don't enjoy them. I find the whole execution to be very immersive and engaging but a bad movie is a bad movie and despite some promise "The Devil Inside" is just that. *.5/5

This has to be one of the worst films i have ever had the privilege of paying for.... From the outset the film has nothing to offer a viewer. I would urge anyone tempted by the trailer, which incidentally is the, dare i say the best bits of the film rolled into 2 minutes not to bother. Take the £25 that it costs these days to see a film for 2 and go to B&Q purchase 2 tins of nice coloured paint, chuck it on the floor and watch it dry !!! failing that spend the £25 on a really sharp fork and stick in in your eye....it will be 100% more exciting, and entertaining than this film called "The Devil Inside" Having said all this i do feel sorry for the person who directed it as he or she is clearly in the wrong profession. Yours Kindly The Devil Inside..... Dave Hancock

reviews.review_title: The Exorcist descends into a Blair Witch style pseudo-documentary.
reviews.content: The opening snippet was from 30oct1989 detailing a 911 call. The caller, Maria Rossi, claims to have killed three people.We jump the shark immediately thereafter. The next part of the film is 'found footage' or whatever nice phrase one uses to describe Blair Witch style worse-than-useless camera work. Someone follows the cops around the crime scene.Priest in the kitchen with the monkey wrench to the head. Nun bludgeoned in the basement with something. Priest hung in the basement with the rope. Signs that a chair was used to restrain a subject.The daughter, Isabella Rossi does a film (oi, film within a film) to help Isabella understand what went on with her mother. This film is not very good either. It's sort of better than the police mess, but not by that much.The interleaved television station news footage also sucked rocks. The main part of the narrative (outside experts who are not in Isabella's film) is recorded in a fourth style, which looks quite competent. The many cuts among these styles makes the film look like a hodge-podge of nonsense circling the bowl after flushing.After being found not guilty by reason of insanity, Maria was committed to the South Hartford State Asylum. A bit later, Maria is transferred to the Centrino Mental Hospital for the Criminally Insane in Rome, Italy. This is curious. One hopes for future exposition of motivation. Some facts came to Isabella in May of 2009 from her father. Maria was the restrained subject in the room; the two priests and the nun were performing an exorcism on Maria. The father died three days later.Eight minutes in. I hate this movie. Isabella's film is so badly made it hurts to watch it.Isabella contacts the exorcism school, and they allow her to conduct interviews and to film classes and the like. Nice of them; of course, they have been doing who knows what to Maria for 20 years.The video of the possessed patients that is shown in the school is of a fifth style, which is the worst of them all: gray on gray, low contrast, small images, iffy sound.The admission to Centrino was described to Isabella's father by the Church as an act of forgiveness. Perhaps the Church was asking for forgiveness from him for what they did to his wife.Isabella's film traces her route into Centrino, then her discussion with the chief medic, then the first visit with Maria. Maria is largely non-responsive. Maria keeps saying connect the cuts for a while. She does not recognize Isabella or the likelihood of her being her daughter. She tells Isabella that she should not have killed her child, then goes off the deep end.She meets with two of the exorcists, Ben Rawlings and David Keane, and shows them the interviews. Isabella and the exorcists delve into what's legal and not regarding exorcisms post 1999, when the Church changed the rules on the subject. They convince Isabella and crew to witness one of their off-the-books exorcisms.That involved quite a performance by Bonnie Morgan.Isabella, Keane, and Rawlings discuss what, if anything, they can do for Isabella's mother Maria.They finagle getting into Centrino and seeing Maria semi-privately with Maria in a highly medicated state. Maria goes to sleep on them, which is a sign that they are barking up the wrong tree. The Maria goes off on them, screaming with eyes widely dilated, and then proceeding to say all sorts of nasty things, in German and English.The hospital staff intervene. No surprise there.They consider options; they could approach the Church with the new video, or they could use Doctor Costa's recommendation might get a transfer back to the States.Things start to fall apart toward the end. The camera man, the exorcists, and Isabella are all upset and on edge. The Church is investigating the incident at Centrino, for one thing, and Michael is feeling massively unappreciated. David nearly drowns a baby that he was baptizing. Things get worse after that.-----Scores------Cinematography: 0/10 Uses many styles, most of which are terrible to look at.Sound: 6/10 Uneven.Acting: 8/10 The actors are fairly good at faking documentary style. The contortionist Bonnie Morgan was impressive as Rosa Sorlini.Screenplay: 8/10 Reasonably good for clear narrative and exposition of motivations. I would have rated this four stars if the camera work had been competent.

Fell asleep in this nonsense at least twice. Demonic possession; yeah right. The movie is mainly over the top campiness. With hand held camera's etc., the director is trying to make the film seem realistic, but really has the effect of being an irritant. The film makers want the viewer to believe this picture is somehow based on a true story, and that too is completely false. Instead of demons the possessed in this film are more like zombies and its a pity Dracula did not make an appearance. For putting me to sleep I can give just above the lowest mark:2/10.

reviews.review_title: I don't care what none of y'all think, I loved it...
reviews.content: FINALLY a scary movie that lives to it's billing. Shot in documentary style like The Blair Witch Project, it contains some of the freakiest moments I've witnessed in this genre of late, and the excellent direction maximises the impact of every shake of the lens and bang in the background. The possessed humans are seriously creepy with their guttural voices and eerie gurning, not to mention the wall-climbing and contortion. The participants FEEL real too, and as we invest in their fate the tension is ratcheted up to almost unbearable levels.IMDb (My favourite movie site) has calculated an average rating of 4.1 for this from over 12'000 users who have voted, which I think is just ludicrous. What's the matter, because there's a bit of SUBTLETY employed here and not some guy in a hockey mask running about hacking up campers, it somehow devalues it? RUBBISH. Open your mind, close the curtains and watch from behind your sofa. If you appreciate well-made, solidly structured, gripping horror films... You'll love it. If you don't, then kindly never read any of my reviews ever again. And leave your keys on the table. 7/10

Just saw the movie today. I really loved the production. The time line really helped place an order of events effect on the story. It made the film very realistic. I felt as if I was watching an actual documentary. The Vatican, Catholic Church and Exorcisms have always fascinated me. Very thought provoking. Made me wonder just what the Vatican really keeps hidden. The portrayals of the demon possessed actors was by far the best I have seen to date. I felt as if I was in the room with them. The ending was surprising, leaving me with several questions unanswered, which hopefully allows room for a sequel. Overall, it is a good movie!

A bland news story. A dull protagonist. Screeching. Washed out shots of mildly creepy looking buildings. A sleep inducing lecture on demons. A misty eyed nun. More screeching. Crosses. Exorcisms so boring they make The Tree Of Life look like a fast paced action epic. Various cameras which have broken zooms. Annoying possessed women doing gymnastics. Darkened areas. Cursing. A hospital. An asylum. A church. A school. Random demonic possessions. Exposition. Whining. Scares which consist of people screeching and contorting and...that's it. A stupid finale which makes no sense. A car crash which represents the movie perfectly. A web link. These are the elements that make up The Devil Inside, a lame, laughably awful and utterly worthless mess. After many awful found footage movies, we finally come to the perfect piece of evidence for opposers of the genre. This is surely, undeniably one of the worst movies in a genre full of god-awful films ever.There isn't one scary moment in The Devil Inside. All it is are cameras zooming around as possessed people screech, curse, do gymnastics and fly around. That's literally it, with intermissions of boring characters sitting around and explaining the plot. TDI may have made over a hundred times its budget at the box office but unfortunately it is less scary than a kiddy coaster at a LEGOLAND theme park. TDI is one of the most insultingly lazy films ever and absolutely no-one was trying. Every single person involved was about as good at their job as a tortoise is at winning a 100m sprint. It is a series of horror conventions, stripped to their minimum and devoid of any character or depth, pasted together. There is no kind of purpose for the Devil Inside to exist, as it fails in every single department. Even the most loyal horror fan will be unimpressed by this tedious mess and it just isn't scary at all. Likely the worst film of 2012, this is only 80 minutes but feels like 180. The worst found footage ever. And I've seen Paranormal Activity 4.0/10

OK, before we start, I LOVE, the found footage style of filmmaking. I loved Cloverfield, Blair Witch, all three Paranormal Acitities, Chronicle, Quarantine, REC, I even liked Diary of the Dead, the Last Exorcism, and though Apollo 18 was OK. But there have been movies done in this style that I didn't like. Zombie Diaries, The Last Broadcast, and Monster, and while this film isn't as bad as Monster, it's still pretty lame.The movie doesn't really do the found footage style well. Just take a camera, film the exorcism, you don't need that many cameras. The acting is pretty bad, I could tell they were trying, but they didn't do it for me. It isn't scary, it isn't funny. The only cool thing about it was the exorcism scene. It was actually kind of cool. I would tell more about the film, but I can't remember much of it.I knew what the ending was because I saw Brad Jones and Jerrid Foiles review it, so it didn't tick me off as much as it would have, but it was bad, really really bad.
Seems to be based on a real exorcism case that started 30 years ago. In all the exorcism streaming movie craze in the early 2010s this is a must watch.

109 reviews have been posted IMDb prior to this one. 9 thought it was a good film. 2 thought it was the most hilarious comedy they'd seen in years.What I'd like to know is, "why is that 10% listed first?" I can only assume that these early "good" reviews were written by persons whom would benefit personally from this film succeeding.The balance of the reviews seem to agree with mine. This movie is a waste of your time and money. Although I found myself continually thinking during the movie "The Blair Witch Exorcism." Honestly it felt like the film was 6 parts Blair witch, 3 parts rosemary's baby and one part exorcist--that one part only because exorcism is the core theme behind the story.Like many poorly made films, this one places a preponderance of scenes inside in dark rooms and basements. This allows inept directors and writers to hide their inadequacies behind an ill deserved claim of artistic license. This film is neither artistic, nor scary. The best that it manages to deliver is a "creepy" feeling throughout--with a few really loud screams and a couple of noteworthy contortions. If you want a good scare, check out some classic Hitchcock--obviously the creators of this film have never seen the kind of real scare Hitchcock could deliver on film.If you absolutely loved the Blair witch project, you'll like this film--maybe. The faux Documentary worked for Blair exclusively because it hadn't been done before. Well, this film doesn't have that advantage. The shaky camera work detracts from what could have been a good storyline--can't these directors figure out that too much of one thing isn't good? The same persistent camera work detracted from cloverfield much in the same way that the long shot detracted from Children of Men. either of these types of shots can work well in small doses, perhaps even in moderation, but don't do it through the whole film.There were a few scenes in this film that DIDN'T use the archival type footage, probably because they couldn't figure out how to do internal auto scenes with it. This of course disrupts whatever suspension of disbelief the audience has managed to maintain because the camera work in these few shots is so dissimilar to the rest of the footage that it's painfully obvious that the shots are non-archival.Overweighed by the horrible cinematography, it's difficult to discern the actors and actresses performance. I imagine they, more than the theatre audiences will be horrified at this movie. They may live in fear for years for what this film will do to their careers.

reviews.review_title: The Devil Inside is a horribly written rehashing of all exorcism movies that came before it.
reviews.content: The Devil Inside 1.5 out of 4 StarsWhat I expected from The Devil Inside and what actually appeared on screen were two entirely different things. This may sound good considering I wasn't expecting much for an early January movie by William Bell. That wasn't the case. The Devil Inside is a horribly written rehashing of all exorcism movies that came before it. It continues with the same idea of demonic possession that other movies— such as The Exorcism of Emily Rose and The Exorcist—have driven into the ground. The Devil Inside offers only one small stylistic change by doing the movie like a documentary. It doesn't work.Even if this movie wasn't a rehashing of old Hollywood trash, it still would be a terrible movie. When it comes to any type of writing, there is a very simply rule that MUST be followed: It is better to show rather than tell. This means that you should show a person's personality or background rather than having it spelled out. The screenwriters—William Bell and Matthew Peterman—are completely unaware of this concept. The only character development is given when the actor looks directly into the camera and tells their story. You will not care what happens to these characters. In fact, the pain they suffer is rather humorouseven though it obviously shouldn't be.I cringed several times at the dialog. Considering this movie was made to look like a documentary, it is essential that the dialog feels natural. It almost never does. There's even a point when the "filmmaker" is left speechless and simply mutters "I don't knowI don't knowI don't know" to himself. To add to this, the footage is meant to come across as raw and uncut. This is supposed to make it feel more realistic. Instead, it comes across as lazy filmmaking. Poor editing. Poor Dialogue. Poor acting. Why, then, did I not give it a lower rating? The two key exorcism scenes and the ending sequence were enjoyable despite its obvious shortcomings. The exorcism scenes are long. This is where the uncut footage actually works for the movie. These long scenes pull you in and actually add tension (something that is missing through the rest of the movie). It's an upside to the movie. Actually, it's the only upside to the movie.I can't, in good faith, recommend this movie for anyone. Don't see it. Just don't. I spent a good deal of effort at the beginning of the movie trying not to get seasick from the unstable camera (another documentary aspect that makes the movie worse). The Devil Inside is a bad excuse of a horror movie. If you want a real exorcism movie, just go rent the movie where it all began—The Exorcist.

reviews.review_title: In spite of poor comments there are moments when this film seems to try to make a point
reviews.content: For starters let me say I get all the comments about films about exorcism having done all this before, repetition of previous attempts, the hand held cameras, and so on. But this film did not strike me as a attempt to invoke horror in the watching audience so much as trying to suggest that exorcism is not about good versus evil - it is the two sides of the same coin. It was as if the opening scenes were about ignorance about what good and evil are. Indeed the film hinges of a very simple phrase used very early in the film - "you need to witness an exorcism for yourself" - amongst an audience simply watching a recording of an exorcism. For me that was suggesting that no amount of exposure to cinema stuff is going to change your minds about anything.And so the film rather demolished its own reason for being made in one simple piece of dialogue, and yet the plot was a little more complex than that. And so the unraveling of the horror scenes and "how did they do that" (see credits) was a little pointless unless the film was trying hard to say something else and failed because so many people have marked it down.Personally I'd like to see the story done again with a little more time spent on the characters who do give us a clear idea of what the writer was trying to say but it just gets lost in all the horror scenes. Even some belt-line dialogue seems to fall out of place because the scene was not being carried correctly. And the unpleasantness (or the real seat of terror as words and actions rather than just actions) is lost because it is just another shock layered upon shock.And so it is overdone and ends up being less of a dish because of it. And yet the acting is at least up to cinema standards and better in some scenes. It is just a great pity the people behind it didn't make better use of promising material.

The Devil Inside is a quasi-good exorcism movie in the "found footage" sub-genre of horror. The camera work is good and the reason for the taping of the incidents in the film is also explained pretty well. Visually, this film trumps many other exorcism films in the mixture of subtle horror and shrieking terror. You notice little things that point toward demonic possession, and then you are confronted with clear signs. This makes for a nice mix; the viewer with the critical mind will get more, I think out of this film than the viewer who is less critically minded when it comes to dissecting the meaning in films.All of this is not to say, however, that this film is without flaws, because it's absolutely not. The main problems to my mind are how unexplained many of the film's phenomenon are early on and the lack of early characterization that would be of infinite value towards the end of the movie...after the "lights go out" scene in the mental hospital. For the post-"light go out" events to really have impact, we need to better know and understand our characters and who they are BEFORE this scene and the dynamic change in the film. Also, the explanations and resolution that comes toward the end are very poor. We are left with thin explanations and frail resolution. We know what happens to the demons, but if we were told more, the film could have been much better. It simply ends too chaotically and suddenly.The film seemed quite short to me; about 30 more minutes might have granted the time necessary to fix some of these problems.Also, there are some unrealistic bits... When los policia and the hospital staff get to chasing you, and you still manage to just walk right out of the hospital dragging an unconscious, demon-possessed murderer with you?? Nah... not too believable.Overall, I give this one a 4; not the worst in the world, but not really worth paying for, either. The Exorcist and The Last Exorcism are much better films if you want to watch some truly captivating demonic shenanigans.

OK, I understand why people would think that the ending is bad. It is a bad ending for a movie, sure, but the thing is it made sense. That is what demons do. If you were to look up demonology, and I'm not saying that it is real, that is what Demons do to people. So yes, the ending was bad from a movie point of view, but from a logical point of view, it was real, and that is what I think they were going for. The movie itself was good, mostly surprise things, and the one exorcism was mainly for shock value. I give the movie 8/10, for minor flaws, but overall a good movie. Scared the hell out of me a few times. And as I said, for all of the nay sayers, the behaviour of this movie was for what Demons really do, by demonology reports and lore.

I'd say that's about 90 minutes of my life I'll never get back. What complete garbage this movie is. No plot to follow and it just felt like it was rehashing of "real life" events. Not to mention that the acting and direction were atrocious. I don't understand how people can waste their money on something like this. I'd really like to know what the whole point of watching these movies are. Thank god some people have the decency to vote this low and its official rating should be even lower. To point out how laughably bad this was, I literally laughed my ass off in one exorcism scene. This is how mediocre and dumb this movie can get. This is really one of those movies in which you should listen to the bad reviews and comments, as it is not even worthy of being mentioned as a bad movie. Time wasting is what this is.

Until I saw this movie, I had never before been in a theatre where, at the end of a film, there is a collective groan of disappointment. One young man in the back helpfully yelled out his quick assessment of the film: "that sucked!". The concept had enormous potential, as evidenced by the $35 million this movie brought in on the weekend. Unfortunately, the execution did not live up to the potential. There was an attempt to build up the characters, but the movie was too short to do so effectively. Most importantly, it wasn't scary. The only time the audience jumped was when they dubbed in a loud audio distortion during the exorcisms - a traditional but very cheap trick to startle the audience when fear is not in the cards. There are lots of great movies playing now. This isn't one of them. Go see something else.

reviews.review_title: Not worth watching it any price even free
reviews.content: I'll just cut to the chase, found footage movies or movie shot as if they were mock documentaries.. they suck. This movie is no different. My morning breath is scarier than this film. Not every movie can be Blair Witch. Nuff said

This movie is raw, unadulterated trash. What's funny is that most of its mercifully short runtime is taken up by an average found footage film that does little to distinguish itself from any other. It's a found footage film about a young woman who tries to discover the truth behind her mother's supposed demonic possession. As a possession movie and a found footage film, there's nothing you've never seen before. It could've just been an average horror movie left in the depths of obscurity. However, there is one thing that makes this movie go from being average at best to one of the worst movies ever in mere seconds: the ending. This is without a doubt the worst movie ending in the history of cinema, and that's saying something. The laziness, the greed, and the ways it plays with the audience are simply inexcusable. This goes beyond just being lazy; it tries to connect to the world outside of the film at the expense of the film itself. If you look at The Blair Witch Project when that came out back in '99, its marketing campaign incorporated real-world things like missing posters. It was excellent marketing for the movie. This, on the other hand, is a movie that is marketing. I get that it's supposed to add a sense of reality to the movie, but the way it does it is the worst possible way to do so. To go further into detail is to tread in spoiler territory. In a weird way, I kind of recommend this movie. Not because it's anything resembling good, but rather because the ending is so shockingly awful that it needs to be seen to be believed. Not only is this the worst horror movie I've ever seen, but this is also a possible candidate for being in the top 5 worst movies I've ever seen.

This is not a movie, this is nothing. Absolutely NOTHING happens in the movie, where is the history? Where is the evolution? At the final scene I laughed, like, that is the movie? reviews.review_title: Clichéd, predictable and can't establish its own identity
reviews.content: The Devil Inside is a mad hybrid of various different films, ranging from The Exorcist, to Blair Witch, to Paranormal Activity – with all the interest, terror and excitement of those films cast out like an unclean spirit. The film draws on so many other sources that it has trouble establishing its own identity.Another film attempting to cash in on the recent handy-cam craze, it is a faux-documentary that follows a woman trying to discover what went wrong in her mother's exorcism 20 years prior, which resulted in the deaths of three people and a life-long spell for her mother in an insane asylum.A fairly unoriginal, but decent enough premise. The film does actually make some interesting commentary on the bureaucracy of the Catholic Church, and contains one or two well-timed scares. But the film is let down by clichéd jump-out-of-your-seat moments that you can see coming from a mile away, like the unexplained orchestral booming noise that occurs whenever the camera looks at something scary, and a ridiculously abrupt ending that stops the film dead in its tracks.If you're gonna go with the whole "found-footage" thing, you have to keep it discreet. It's dangerous to show too much, whereas the likes of Blair Witch and Paranormal Activity did mostly suggestion work. Heck, even Cloverfield didn't let you see too much of the monster. The Devil Inside just keeps throwing too much in your face, and it becomes predictable.

I'm a sucker for these kind of films although the documentary format is getting a bit old. Despite damning reviews therefore I saw it, and it was better than expected and certainly better than other movies I've seen. The premise of the story actually wasn't bad, take away the bigger production and indomitable presence of Anthony Hopkins in The Rite, I think this story had more potential. It was cliché, but there were some creepy moments and some of the supporting cast turned in quite compelling performances, there were also under currents to each supporting cast's character that in my opinion outshone the main lead.Which brings me to a problem with the movie, the lead character played by Andrade was flat as a pancake, lacked any screen presence and generated absolutely no sympathy from the audience, beside which the two priests played by Quarterman and Helmuth absolutely shone in comparison for me. The movie's possession scenes I found well done and although some people thought the frenetic ending strange I found it quite good and so much better than so many films that limp into the end. This film could have been much better, throw in a strong lead actress tweak some directorial and style issues and address how the documentary camera work doesn't quite get itself right, throw a bit of style and Constantine and more screen time the Priest's way and we'd have a winner. Alas we do not, but not bad. If you've put in the time for Paranormal activity you may as well for this one, don't expect much and you may be surprised.

reviews.review_title: Don't waste your time OR your money
reviews.content: I was able to see this through a VIP pass which I appreciate, but it was far more entertaining to make fun of than to actually take this movie seriously. My friend couldn't have said it better, "Blair Witch part V". Your taken on a ride to Rome, which seems to be where the budget went. For a small while I thought that the movie was really going to go somewhere. I think the writers ran out of ideas how to do the closing because afterwords, the whole audience (the ones left) booed at the screen. I think if this was made into a short film, it would have had a chance, but that's about it.. For those who don't write reviews here, when you see one star, its because you cant chose "no stars" 1 =awful. Normally I read reviews, but this is my first because i really felt so strongly about my opinion of this movie..

reviews.review_title: It wasn't that bad! Well the ending, yes... but okay.
reviews.content: I enjoyed this movie, and I do think it's very underrated! I know, the ending was absolutely awful, but it was an entertaining exorcism movie that had a fair amount of interesting and scary moments.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as most here say
reviews.content: I actually really enjoyed most of this film. It is what the preview says it is. If you went in expecting anything other than a found footage movie then you did no homework. A quick Google search tells you what it is, so simmer down folks. The idea is great, the acting is solid, the direction - what little is required in the found footage sub genre - is O.K. What isn't okay is it is in the hands of writers who had no idea what to do with the concept. Poor character development (can anyone tell me why Michael has chosen this project, who he is, where he's from, anything?) is not new to this genre but some would help. We are used to cop out endings with these films. We are NOT used to full blown "we don't have a clue what to do next" endings. That's what we get here. It's been a long time since I was in a full theater of booing, angry people at the end of a film, but I was tonight. That's not really fair, it's better than that. Just don't expect any resolution whatsoever.

When I saw the previews for this movie I knew that I wanted to go to the theater and see it. I questioned myself about seeing it multiple times because everyone was saying that it was awful and giving it a miserable rating. I'm glad that I chose to go see it. There were a few times where I knew if I were in that situation I would have been scared to death. I do agree about the ending being awful. I feel like they could have made this movie at least two hours long instead of a very short hour and twenty seven minutes. On the way home from the theater my girlfriend and I thought up of many better ending possibilities that could have taken place in this movie. Overall I would definitely watch this movie again but I probably would never purchase it.

*MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS*Well, here we are. 2012, and there is yet to be a film based on possession and exorcism that lives up to and exceeds the reputation of the original 1978 "The Exorcist".While the film plays as a documentary-type movie, it works little to none in favour of the film. It follows Isabella on her mission to find her mother, Rosa, who is now in a mental hospital in Rome, Italy. It's a typical "Paranormal Activity" performance from the actors, who constantly pay attention to the camera, and are aware of its presence. Yes, if it was real, obviously they would be aware during the exorcism scenes, but the characters/actors are constantly referring to the camera as if it's an actual character. Now, as far as horror, building the tension is the only area in which this film succeeds. We know something is going to happen, and for the a few moments, disturbing. Yet, it plays on it way too much, and is used excessively. Personally, this only worked for the scene where we witness the first exorcism the Priests perform. After, it becomes slightly irritating being dragged on through the moment. As with most possession films, we have the typical "noting is wrong with her" characters, and soon, we find yet again, the body-hopping-demon that was witnessed not too long ago (a certain flop called "Drag Me To Hell" ring any bells?) makes a silver screen appearance. It's almost sad how many times we see this used, and audiences know, and can/will predict the outcomes of the film. If you're a movie goer regardless of what people say, and want to see if you'll enjoy it, I say go ahead. I'm that type as well. I like to form my own opinions. But, if you've seen the trailer...well, you've seen the disturbing parts....that's all the film is, slightly disturbing. Not scary in the least. Oh well...maybe one day we'll get a really scary movie.

reviews.review_title: Poor shaky cam done on the cheap with almost no plot.

reviews.review_title: It had me bluffed at first

On the hire DVD it did not show the cast credits at first, and it kept stalling but I saw enough to see it was a fiction/documentary style movie.I think it was well done especially the woman bleeding on the bed and in the hospital. reviews.review_title: I stopped watching ten minutes before the ending...

reviews.review_title: I knew it was bad because of his rating, but i wanted to see it.

So i will start with the only good thing about this movie : it makes jump ! Yes i did jump 2 or 3 times and it's not the first horror movie as i watch. And now, let's talk about all bad things, so 3/4 of the movie.I watched "The Rite" and it was so-so, "The Last Exorcism" was also so-so. "Devil Inside" mix these two movies and it's very bad. The movie takes place in Vatican like in "The Rite" and it starts with "The Vatican doesn't endorse this movie". Seriously what was the point about it? The audience laughed when it appeared. The story isn't original because there is a scene in this movie which has been remake and remake again, it's when someone is possessed by a demon, and insult the priest who tries to exorcise her. That's always been fun and doesn't make this film scary, the audience also laughed.This movie use the "Horror Reality" process like "Paranormal Activity", "REC" and "Blair Witch Project". They interview peoples and we can see their name each time we see them.As shocking as it can be, this movie reached 33 millions of dollars in 1 week in American Box Office! reviews.review_title: Why are you people watching this garbage???
reviews.content: Okay, I admit, I have not seen this movie- BUT- I work in a movie theater. So I've seen the lines and the crowds and the mobs of people rushing into my theater just dying to see this movie. WHY??? What is the attraction here? It's a crappy, low budget, cliché exorcism movie. Nothing new to see here. No one even remotely famous is in it. Why the hell are so many people rushing to see this steaming pile of cellu-poop??? My theater is in a small town, not usually too busy, but we've been selling out this show and I don't understand why. I'm at the theater door every time the movie ends. I hear every person's reaction to the movie and EVERY SINGLE PERSON who has seen this movie at my theater has HATED it. They boo at the end, they bitch and moan, and I'm like "Well what made you think it'd be any good anyhow???" Also- In my theater, we only refund your money in the first 30 minutes of a movie. We give you half an hour to decide if it's crap. After that, sorry tough luck, we don't make the movies we just show 'em. Can't please everyone. Do your research before you decide what to see. If you want your money back, write a letter to the director or the producer. Keep your $10, stay home, and rent "The Exorcist" (1973).

The folks who put this movie out, Paramount, handed out little slips of paper asking for our comments on Facebook or Twitter. They stressed that we should mention it was a free screening. Thank God it was. If I'd paid for it I'd be darned upset. Fernanda Andrade plays Isabella Rossi, a woman who is investigating the hospitalization of her mother, Maria Rossi, played by Suzan Crowley, following three murders committed by her mother in 1989. The three murders were of two priests and a nun during an unauthorized exorcism. After her trial, Maria was found not guilty by reason of insanity and hauled off to an Italian psych hospital by the Vatican. Now Isabella wants to know more about mom, partly in fear of what might be waiting for her. The movie is told in documentary style as in the Blair Witch Project. We are introduced to Inout Grama as Michael the documentarian, and Simon Quarterman and Evan Helmuth as priests Ben and David, respectively. Ben and David believe that the Church has it all wrong. That they, as young priests and exorcists can do it better. Can you see where this is going? The movie starts out slow and stays slow for quite a while. Several people left after the first 30 min or so. Crowley gives an admirable performance as a madwoman, and as I said to Betsy afterward part of the movie was just about like being back on the the wards with some of my most acute patients. But it was all predictable, none of it scary. I wanted to give everyone a round of IM Geodon or Valium during the in-hospital exorcism, depending on whether they were psychotic or just way over neurotic. There were plot holes and an abrupt ending after 80 min. that left you going "Huh?" While in line we were given a small box of incense sticks. Why? I don't have a clue. Incense plays no role in the movie. I also got a down-loadable album, again not sure why. And though I didn't win in a radio promotion prize wheel game, I got a set of chemical hand warmers as a consolation. So all in all I came out slightly ahead, I guess.

reviews.review_title: A couple of moments but overall doesn't work
reviews.content: The biggest problem with this movie is its pretensions to being a fake documentary. Generally for this to work, the actors have to look and act like real people and the visuals have to be presented as if they are really happening, no matter how bizarre what is being portrayed appears.It hits problems early on – Fernanda Andrade is way too good looking for us to buy her role and the actors are far too actorly, it's obvious that they are delivering dialogue and not just speaking candidly. This is at its worst early on both with the "to camera" monologues, the discussion at the school for exorcism and the round table chat in the pub. These are the scenes that are supposed to establish that what we're seeing is real, if we buy that it will make the later scenes more shocking. The lines are delivered as if it were a high school stage play when improvised dialogue around a theme would have worked much better.In addition, the constant switching of POVs from camera to camera wouldn't be necessary if the footage was real – if you have real footage of an exorcism, why would you cut into it? What's likely to be more visually interesting than someone possessed by a supernatural force? A real documentary filmmaker would present the sequence uncut, warts and all and let it speak for itself.Because the early scenes don't work and the filmmakers reveal a lack of confidence in their shock footage, it pushes the audience away when we're supposed to be drawn in and ultimately the film has flubbed its trump card. If you can't suspend disbelief that what you are seeing is a documentary then the film as a whole just doesn't work.Despite the bad press the flick has got, there are a couple of well executed sequences – the main camera view of the first exorcism includes some bizarre imagery and the sequences where we are introduced to the idea of demonic transference by the priest attempting to drown a baby in the baptism font and the same priests suicide are both well realised and presented matter-of-factly.Unfortunately, by this point we aren't buying the fake doc pretense, these are nothing but nice ripples on a lake of dissatisfaction and overall, despite a very brief running time, the film is actually quite boring.

reviews.review_title: 'The Devil Inside' punches well above it's weight, and delivers some edge-of-seat creepiness. A Ghoulish Treat.
reviews.content: This micro-budget offering from Paramount's 'Insurge Pictures' stable, achieves some genuine horror, and succeeds in adding a few novel twists to the Exorcism Movie genre. With this style of movie being so well trodden now; it is no surprise that 'The Devil Inside' does contain some familiar themes, but what's different here, is how the horror elements, have been adjusted and re-combined to render them just that little bit darker. Once you spot this is going on, it even starts to become a 'thing of itself' within the movie, which is fairly novel and bizarre. You begin to recognize familiar horror elements, and track how they have been re-moulded. In itself, this re-hashing of pre-existing ideas is nothing new, and not a problem at all. It actually becomes quite fascinting to observe how effective this approach is, as the scenes play through. There appear to be shades of influence (among others), from The Exorcist, Constantine, The Ring, The Blair Witch Project, and As Above - So Below. Despite the pros and cons of this approach, Director, William Brent Bell still manages to cunjure a coherent vision by sharing in both the writing and editing credits, which has certainly paid off. Some movies never let you forget they were made on a limited production budget. Perhaps it's something to do with the quality of the acting, direction, lighting, set composition, or all of the above. The Devil Inside, phases in and out of this phenomenon, so in one moment it's definately low-budget fare, and then in the next, it has suddenly become something else; something outsisde of that limitation. Though it stands on the shoulders of some better movies, if you can forgive it's shortcomings; 'The Devil Inside' punches well above it's weight, and delivers some edge-of-seat creepiness. A Ghoulish Treat.

This film didn't work, it just seemed dumb and stupid. I don't see why anyone will enjoy this film at tall. Firstly the acting is horrible, if you are going to make a documentary style movie then you have to believe the characters are real people and all I could see was actors doing a bad job. The acting was not helped by the the script which was just terrible, there is no way I could believe this is how peolpe talk and behave, and once again with a film like this you need to see these people as believable and frankly I couldn't care less about any of them. Further more, nothing irritates me more than stupid jump scares, they don't do anything else than ruin any tension there was in a scene before hand, it doesn't add to the film scare factor in anyway, and this film has a fair few of them that are plain and simply stupid. Even about 20 mins into the film I really didn't care about what was going on, what was going to happen with the characters or the story, it did nothing to get me interested, and everything after that just got worse. Which brings me to the ending, I think I can easily say it is dumbest ending of a film ever, it made absolutely no sense it truly felt like the writers couldn't think how to wrap up the film, it was just so stupid! All I can say is, don't see movie, it is a complete waste of time!

reviews.review_title: A disgusting insult to any genre fan.
reviews.content: (Halloween Horror Reviews #11)If you are a lover of horror cinema then please heed my warning. There are very few films that I will beg you not to see, this is one of them. But above this, know that:This film is a lie.Every thing contained in the film's advertising is a lie, it is not scary, it is not shocking and it isn't even complete. I feel no shame in listing this review as 'Non-spoiler', because there is nothing to spoil. This is among the most predictable and generic horror films I have ever seen. Nothing of originality, nothing to offer a veteran horror fan, and even less for a newcomer to the genre. When I rate a film 1 star, I mean to say that not only does the film have no value, it has anti-value. It causes nothing but harm to its peers and embarrasses an entire community of films by association.The film's acting is a joke. Delivered with the passion of an Ikea lamp, and with the originality of bad haircut. The 'main characters' are unlikable assholes, portrayed as much through the dialogue as the acting. The film's 'script' is a dirty, sodden dishcloth, every jump-scare is a stain upon it. This horrendously trite slice of nothingness failed to even achieve an 85 min runtime, likely because they avoided inconveniences such as character or plot. The film cares so little for its audience that it even insults the .01% of said audience who enjoyed it. It does this by failing to end. The film has NO ENDING. The last frame of the film is a link to a now defunct web domain (the studio was so cheap it only paid for 6 months on the website, a website referenced in every version of the film!).This crap surpasses Frankenstein (1994) as the worst horror film I have ever reviewed. It's monumental financial success is a testament to how we have all been played for cattle, steered into the corporate slaughterhouse and reduced to chowder.

After all so many bad reviews, ratings, blogs, (vlongs via youtube) I decided to give this movie a shot. I am going to tell you right here it now, FORGET THE BAD REVIEWS AND FORM YOUR OWN OPINION. Forget about comparing this movie to others, go watch it with an open mind, and have no expectations because you will be surprised!! I would love a part 2 to this! I recommended this to those who like graphic detail to a realistic scenario because this does just that. Forget the rating, take the movie for what it is, it will leave you searching for answers.

reviews.review_title: This scale doesn't let me go lower than 1. WARNING SPOILER ALERT...
reviews.content: Never have I been so disappointment with a movie as I have been with the Devil Inside. Believe me, I've seen some sucky movies in my life (i.e Epic Movie, Date Movie, etc...) but this one wins the prize as the worst movie ever. For one, the ludicrous plot, possessed woman who is a US citizen offs three American priests and gets extradited to Italy to serve her years in at the Centrino Hospital for the Criminally Insane which for your information doesn't exist. Why would a US Citizen be extradited to Italy to serve in an insane asylum. Well because she killed priests. This means she has to serve time in an insane asylum run by the Vatican. There is no such city or town near Rome or in Italy named Centrino that has a Hospital for the Criminally Insane especially one that is run by the Vatican. The word "Centrino is a denomination of the word Cientro which is the Italian word for Center. In other words "Centrino Hospital for the Criminally Insane" is actually "Center or Central Hospital for the Criminally Insane", very creative. I further support the fact the hospital was made up because of the fact that the guard for the hospital speaks very crappy Italian with an American accent. Talking about accents, most of the characters that are supposed to be Italian are not Italian as they all speak crappy Italian with very bad American accents. I wouldn't hire these people to work as spies in Italy because their crappy American accents would give them away, these people would probably blend in better if they just stuck to English. In fact, during the video showing a girl possessed by a demon the demon who is possessing her speaks Italian with an American accent. This tells me that Demons hold either American or British nationalities. I was born in Italy and I am very good at detecting non-native Italian Speakers especially the ones who have American accents. To be honest I don't think this film was filmed in Italy because why would American actors be hired to portray Italians. Wouldn't it be cheaper to hire Italian actors to play Italians while you are in Italy filming a movie? The next point, while Italy is a very educated country, the odds of finding ordinary Italians (such as the possessed girls mother) speaking English even broken English are very low. In other countries like Germany or Austria your odds of finding someone speaking English is much higher. In the tourist centers such as Rome you will find people who speak English but not in the country side. Out of my entire Italian family only my mom speaks English and that is because she was married to my father who was in the US Army. English is not always used in every day Italian life. The bottom line, this movie sucked big. I don't think you should characterize this as a horror movie because I laughed at most of it. I found it funny that you can get possessed by being burped on. There are so many questions that will never be answered such as what is so scary about a blind person. Yes, I'm talking about the blind nun that is all over the marketing for this film. She is just a passerby in the street and doesn't play any part what so ever in this film. I think even the producers of this piece of garbage felt that their movie sucked so they decided to end it abruptly with that god awful ending. Don't attempt to go to the website at the end of the movie to find answers. You won't get any. The www.therossifiles.com is just a website filled with scenes from the movie. It looks like the producers ran out of ideas and just wanted to make a quick buck which they did. All in all, the only thing scary about this movie is this piece of crap managed to lure me in like a dummy and steal 75 minutes of my life I'll never get back and also my $10 for the ticket. I think I'm just going to out, film some blind people who speak Italian with bad American accents and make my own scary movie and become a millionaire.

The whole story about "exorcisms" have been told time and time again. No one has nailed it since the original "The Exorcist" back in 1973. The majority of them are pretty bleak and bring nothing new to the story. The Devil Inside, unfortunately, suffers from that same fate.This time around, a young mother commits a triple murder while possessed by various demonic spirits. A few years later, the daughter goes looking for an answer and finds more than she bargain for.As the film begins to develop, the tension quickly builds up as we are taken to a walk through of the crime scene. After one cheap scare, the false sense of hope disappear faster than you can say 666. As I mention before, The Devil Inside offers nothing new to the story for the exception of a couple of scenes that will make you jump out of your seats. Unfortunately, this is not enough to mend the damaged inflicted by this fictitious tale. The inconsistencies within the film are far too many to ignore. The movie is supposed to play as a documentary but you will notice that this is not always the case. At times it feels as if you were watching a really low budget horror movie with very bad acting. Yes, as if the bad story wasn't bad enough, the acting in this film was pretty bad but it was the best thing this movie had to offer.Now, put all this mishaps together and add one of the worst ending in film history, what you'll get is The Devil Inside. The overall execution was mediocre at best. This might be scary for a 10 year old kid but not to your general moviegoer and especially not to a avid horror fan. If you want to see (essentially) the same movie with better acting, watch "The Rite" with Anthony Hopkins. It's already on DVD and it wont cost you an arm and a leg. If you are in the mood for some devilish movies, stick to the originals: The Exorcist, The Exorcism of Emily Rose, The Amityville Horror, etc...By Raymond Melendez www.MovieFloss.com

I am so bummed!! I had high expectations for this movie because the previews made this movie looks really scary. I also live for films about exorcisms. Stay away from this movie though, it's not even worth your time even if you are bored out of your mind one day and want to watch a scary flick. Skip this one!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: What the hell was this movie?
reviews.content: Let me start by introducing myself a little: I'm 25 years old and a HUGE horror fan. Not just American, I prefer the Japanese horror. When Isabella finally showed the signs of possession in the hospital, I thought: "Here we go, now the movie will make a turn for the better". But again, I was disappointed. The car ride just was a big mess, creating questions you get no answers to. And then the ending... please! Especially when the words appear on screen about the Rossi files and to check the website. If you want to be freaked out this is a great movie to see in my opinion but I'd leave before the end because the ending left me sorely disappointed.

Set inside the famous Vatican, The Devil Inside tells of a chilling yet not so suspenseful story. Embarking on an adventure to find out what happened to her mom, an Italian woman goes through a series of exorcisms to find out all the answers she needs. Combined with theory, suspense, religion, and found footage, The Devil Inside presents an interesting take on a thriller movie. With found footage present in the film, there is an interesting way to look at how the film was made. Using the shaky camera technique makes the film interesting and keeps the viewer on their toes a little bit more. The film could also be conveyed a lot scarier as well. Due to the way the movie was shot, more people through the movie were based upon a real life story, which was originally intended by the director. Watching The Devil Inside allows the viewer to observe through a critical lens. It goes slightly into the Roman Catholicism religion and uses the Vatican as a base for its exorcisms. Oddly enough, at the beginning of the film, a notice reads that the Vatican had no part to do with the filming of this movie. Throughout this movie, the dialogue becomes very suspenseful. Scenes of the scary mom and her outrageous tantrums occur throughout the movie, which makes it difficult to put together at times. To sum everything up, I truly believe the film could have been made a little better. In this film, the character of the woman is the main focus. She is set out to find answers and clear things up. However, I felt that the role she played was very subtle and not great. The acting I felt could have been better. I also see this film in a point of view perspective where everything that happens is the way the daughter sees it. She knows there is some kind of spirit possessing her mom and knows she needs to get rid of it. Moreover, the film The Devil Inside offers viewers a way to look what is going on by the atmosphere. The woman is constantly dealing with voices and spirits in addition to being inside the Catholic Church. Having the Vatican in the background allows for a good movie setting for this. In conclusion, looking at the visceral way of thinking, I felt that I did not get anything out of it. The movie is not scary and attempts to make use of the exorcism idea to bring that out.

When I realised that this was a 'mock-umentary' I nearly turned it off, but what kept me watching was the acting, or rather the lack of acting. If that sounds bonkers, what I mean is that the actors for the most part pulled off a rare achievement: appearing NOT to be actors, but seeming to be real people. I can only assume that those reviewers who rated the acting as awful spend too much of their time in movieworld and have forgotten how real people sound, i.e. unprepared, off-the-cuff and uncertain rather than speaking as if they obviously know their lines. In this respect, this film was remarkably realistic. On the whole 'exorcism' issue, this film also contained one of the most intelligent debates on the 'Possession versus mental illness' arguments that I've seen. So in conclusion, if you want a formulaic, shock-horror fright-fest, don't watch this. If, however, you want an intelligent film with 'real life' dialogue instead of smoothie-polished Hollywood glitz, and a different take on the 'religion versus science' question of exorcism then watch this with an open mind and enjoy a non-mainstream film.

reviews.review_title: Custom made for your Netflix cue
reviews.content: Don't believe the hype! There's a reason this was dumped into theaters in January -- the usual time studios dump "lesser movies" on an unsuspecting public.Devil Inside does have its moments, and there are some good effects for the gorehounds. But once you get past a pretty good build-up within the first ten minutes, the film loses steam -- FAST! Then again, I don't know if it's THIS movie or the "exorcism subgenre" in general. Other than the original EXORCIST (which is an awesome FILM in addition to being a fantastic horror movie), most exorcism movies are pretty dull.I still put the DEVIL INSIDE above THE LAST EXORCISM (fell apart during the last act) and THE RITE (just awful) and that EMILY ROSE movie (dull), but that's still not saying much.If somebody throws you free tickets -- by all means -- GO! But don't shell out 8 or more dollars for this. Wait for the DVD.SPOILER AHEAD -- I also didn't appreciate an ending that sent me to a freakin' website and/or blatantly set the flick up for a sequel.

reviews.review_title: Good for what it was, though the ending was weak.....
reviews.content: As far as a 'documentary' and exorcism movie done on a low budget, this was not bad at all. They did a good job with the footage, cameras (hardly any of that shaky crap in similar films)and the acting was pretty good. Suzan Crowley in particular (as Maria) did an excellent job in her role.Pretty short coming in at about 1:25, but it was entertaining and that's the point. I didn't go into this thinking I was seeing the Exorcist.The main problem people have with the movie, is the ending. I understand what the filmmakers were trying to do and it was ballsy in a way, to just abruptly end it the way they did. Too many times in movies, endings are predictable and to satisfy the masses, edits are done - and with some moviegoers, they need a more simple explanation and some sort of movie closure. It's not hard to understand the final result of the movie, but they probably should have polished off the ending and left this version as an alternate on the DVD. I never saw this in the movies, but on DVD - so I can understand the boos this movie got by someone paying $10+ a ticket (plus extras) and winding up with this result.Still though, this wasn't bad at all and worth watching at least once if you're a fan of the genre.

I am a huge fan of films in this vein. The rich mythology of Catholicism is entertaining and intriguing - when it is done right. When it is done right, you get excellent thrillers like Constantine or the Exorcism of Emily Rose. When it is done wrong, you get duds like this one.The writing and dialog in this movie were a special brand of terrible. I tend to have reasonably low standards for the kind of acting that will still allow me to feel engaged and invested in a movie. And even so, I was constantly brought out of the movie with thoughts of how forced the tension was being rendered by the actors. The scenes in between the "scary" moments were disjointed and awkward. The "scary" moments left the audience with a general feeling of "what??".I am not the only one that felt this way. When the ending - such as it was - happened and the credits rolled, the entire audience started laughing and heckling the screen. It has been a long time since I felt like I wanted to walk out on a movie, but in this case I wish I had trusted my gut. At least my afternoon could have been salvaged.In short, even with a rich history and mythology to work from, this movie failed to hit the mark of even a mediocre film. The special effects were minimal and tastefully subtle, which is fine. But the acting and the writing were absolutely terrible. The ending looked as though they were about as tired of making the film as I was of watching it. This film is a rental at best. But only if you have a morbid curiosity of how badly a film can be made. Or if you have a "bad movie night" in which you and your friends get together to heckle lousy movies. In which case, this is a must-see.
